urn:contentItem:491K-CVP0-01JM-82JJ-00000-00Investors Worry Cisco's Troubles Reflect Broader Problems in the U.S. Economy2001-04-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:55ZLexisNexisSHOW:HARDBALL 17:00Bill Griffeth; Stephen Roach; Tony Perkins; Jack Kemp; Duncan Hunter; David Dreier Katrina; Vanden Heuvel; John FundNEWS; DOMESTICSHOW# 041700cb.461Investors Worry Cisco's Troubles Reflect Broader Problems in the U.S. EconomyChris Matthews

It's hardly the first big tech company to announce bad news, but today all the talk on Wall Street and out in Silicon Valley was about Cisco Systems. Long considered a blue chip of the new economy, Cisco's networking equipment is the foundation for much of the Internet. But yesterday, the company announced its sales this quarter could be down 30 percent and it will lay off over 8,000 workers. Over the past year, Cisco's stock has lost 80 percent of its value. The company's CEO, John Chambers, told reporters, "This may be the fastest any industry our size has ever decelerated. We never built models to anticipate something of this magnitude."

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOTBE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

CHRIS MATTHEWS, HOST: Cisco Systems announces a big round of layoffs. What can be done? We'll talk to Power America's Jack Kemp. And as U.S. diplomats prepare to sit down with the Chinese, is it time for payback?

I'm Chris Matthews. Let's play HARDBALL.

Well, it's hardly the first big tech company to announce bad news, but today all the talk on Wall Street and out in Silicon Valley was about Cisco Systems. Long considered a blue chip of the new economy, Cisco's networking equipment is the foundation for much of the Internet. But yesterday, the company announced its sales this quarter could be down 30 percent and it will lay off over 8,000 workers. Over the past year, Cisco's stock has lost 80 percent of its value. The company's CEO, John Chambers, told reporters, "This may be the fastest any industry our size has ever decelerated. We never built models to anticipate something of this magnitude."

But last night on CNBC, he held out hope for the future.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOHN CHAMBERS, CEO, CISCO SYSTEMS: I'm still very optimistic about the industry as a whole. We're still very tightly tied to economies and capital spending globally. If somebody can tell us that those are going to be positive, then I'm very comfortable with the 30 to 50 percent growth. If those continue to be very challenging, then obviously we cannot avoid capital spending challenges and will affect our earnings appropriately.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MATTHEWS: So which is it? Is this going to be a quick and dirty recession or a deep slump? We'll talk to Stephen Roach, chief global economist at Morgan Stanley, Tony Perkins of Red Herring and Jack Kemp of Empower America. And we'll look ahead to tomorrow's meeting between the U.S. and the Chinese military. What's at stake as the two sides come face to face?

We begin tonight with CNBC's Bill Griffeth. Bill, what is the reaction on Wall Street to what was said today by John Chambers of Cisco?

BILL GRIFFETH, CNBC CORRESPONDENT: You know, Chris, for a long time in the '90s the analysts on Wall Street said that the stock market had already priced in perfection, that a lot of companies like a Cisco needed to continue with the breakneck pace of growth that they had experienced through much of the '90s. And now the feeling seems to be that the stock market is starting to price in, what shall we say, Armageddon, I mean, you know, something a lot worse than what we've seen the last several years and today on Wall Street for the most part they, I won't say that they took the Cisco warning in stride, but we didn't see a major decline on that company's stock. When all was said and done it was only down about $0.50 in normal trade today, and as you can see there, the major averages on Wall Street actually finished higher and, in fact, tonight from other big companies like Intel and Texas Instruments, we're getting some numbers that suggest that maybe things aren't as bad they would suggest from Cisco.

But the point is, I mean you heard John Chambers say he's still expecting growth of between 30 and 50 percent. That's a lot less than they did in the '90s, but it's still a growth rate that would make any CEO's mouth water. So, you know, they're still growing, but just not as fast as they were back in the '90s.

MATTHEWS: Well, you know, Bill, you cover business and I come from a political background, so there's such a word as spin.

GRIFFETH: You bet.

MATTHEWS: There's also a word called low balling.

GRIFFETH: Yup, yup.

MATTHEWS: Are these guys low balling? People, including Jack Welch, are all these guys out there telling us the bad news to make the, to lower the bench or the marker for what they have to accomplish in each corporation?

GRIFFETH: You know, on any given quarter there may be a bit of that. But when you take it in the aggregate over, you know, a year over year or a two year period, five year period, there's not a whole lot of spin you can do. The numbers don't lie from that standpoint. And, you know, what you're seeing right now, I mean it's all about expectations on Wall Street.

MATTHEWS: Right.

GRIFFETH: And the expectations were very high for a long time and what we're seeing right now is just a matter of expectations perhaps coming back down to a more realistic level. And for Cisco Systems, I mean a Cisco, you know, an Intel, an AOL, I mean a lot of these high fliers, Yahoo! from the '90s and the growth of the Internet, the expectations were just too high. And now we're starting to see that come down to maybe more realistic levels here.

MATTHEWS: Good to see you again, Bill Griffeth of CNBC.

GRIFFETH: Thanks, Christopher.

MATTHEWS: Thanks for joining us on HARDBALL.

We're joined now from New York by Stephen Roach. He's chief global economist at Morgan Stanley. And from San Francisco, our old pal Tony Perkins of Red Herring Communications.

I want to start first with Mr. Roach, a newcomer to the program. Thank you. You're a very prestigious fellow. I've got to ask you the simple question, is the new economy playing by the old rules now but they just didn't know it?

STEPHEN ROACH, MORGAN STANLEY: Absolutely, Chris. I think the new economy went to excess just like the Nasdaq did a year ago and that excess showed up in the form of too many workers that were hired, especially white collar workers, and unfortunately too much capital spending, largely technology. And this recession is all about taking that excess out and it's going to take a while.

MATTHEWS: There was a lot of people talking a or so ago saying you don't have to worry about quarterly profits anymore, that's yesterday's thinking. All you have to do is brand your product. All you've got to do is get everybody to know that you're Amazon.com and the money is going to come in eventually because we're not going to have any more recessions.

ROACH: That was the hype, that was the hope of the new economy. The mantra was scale and scope and it worked well as long as we stayed in this hyper growth path that we were on over the 1995 to mid 2000 period. That boom has gone to bust and we've found we've got too much cost in the system. We're in a deep earnings recession and we've got to take those costs out now.

MATTHEWS: Who won and who lost in this big bubble pop here? Did the young gung ho guys who are in their early '30s or even younger who made all these things happen in high tech, did they make off with a bundle of money and the people who were the stooges the ones who invested?

ROACH: Hard to know the winners and losers. Clearly, the investors who were early in getting in and early in getting out are huge winners and those that hung on for too long, as is usually the case in a bubble, they're the painful losers.

MATTHEWS: Let's get another point of view from our friend Tony Perkins. React to what you just heard critically.

TONY PERKINS, "RED HERRING": Well, I have always been in line with Stephen Roach. In fact, he was quoted amply in my book, "Internet Bubble," which came out in '99. We both were not huge believers in this new economy hype. You talk about spin, Chris, I think John Chambers is doing a little bit of a disservice to our industry. He's spinning the fact that, as Stephen is indicating, he mismanaged his company. He hired too many people, bought too much inventory. He drank the Internet Kool-Aid just like everybody else. He should be apologizing and cutting out the costs, just as Mr. Roach is suggesting he should do.

MATTHEWS: What about the business cycle, Tony? Do you believe in it? Is it here to stay? It's been here, I was just, we're going to be talking with Jack Kemp, but the facts are there. We've had a recession under Reagan when he first came in. We've had a recession under Bush one. We're having a recession, it looks like now, under Bush two. Why don't we acknowledge the fact that recessions are part of life?

PERKINS: They are part of life. We saw an extended boom which, again, was artificially extended because we saw literally hundreds of billions of dollars from V.C.s and the public markets going into these Internet companies that turned out not to be real. But unfortunately for the Ciscos, they bought a bunch of equipment from them artificially inflating their revenue line and now we're in a hangover period. The day of reckoning is here. We should just all admit that we all got sucked into this thing and it's time to go back and running our businesses the way that we should.

MATTHEWS: Well, let's talk about that right now with Stephen Roach. In terms of people out there who are watching who are investors and people who may be venture capitalists even, a bunch of them watching right now, I'm sure they are, what should they be doing?

ROACH: I think they have to be very, very cautious, Chris. The market has, as you indicated at the outset, taken on board an awful lot of bad news. But the problem is that while the market has capitulated, as Bill Griffeth said, on the outlook for this year, it's still too optimistic for next year. Earnings are expected to be up about 16 percent next year. In my opinion, there's no way corporate America is going to hit that.

So I think investors need to stay very defensive, avoiding high risk technology bets at this point, and playing a lot of defensive consumer stocks and possibly even bonds. This is not a time to go back in…

MATTHEWS: That's the choice. That's the choice that was presented on the front page of "USA Today." If you think there's going to be a quick rebound, put your money on stocks to do well in rebounds. If you don't, if you think we're going into a deep trough for a year or so, put your money in those defensive stocks like, and they mentioned cereals, utilities, things like that.

ROACH: I couldn't agree more.

MATTHEWS: What do you think, Tony?

PERKINS: Well, I would…

MATTHEWS: Well, you want people to invest in high tech. I mean you've got an interest here, right? Let's be honest. You love this field. It's your field.

PERKINS: Well, the fact of the matter is is Larry Lindsey, the chief economic adviser, reminded me when I interviewed him last week in the White House that the average investment in I.T. still will get a 30 to 40 percent return on your investment. Michael Dell recently bragged to me that he gets a 250 percent return every time he invests in new computers and new software and the Internet…

MATTHEWS: But that's not the stock, that's not the stock buyer. That's the entrepreneur, right?

PERKINS: Yeah, that's to help companies become more efficient. And if that's the case, there's going to continue to be strong demand for technology goods. I think John Chambers is admitting that once we get through this kind of recalibration period that we'll be back to good growth.

So, you know, long-term I'm optimistic. Larry Lindsey says it's going to be a great decade for technology. I agree with him. It's just that we've got to get through this next several quarters.

MATTHEWS: Well, we've got Jack Kemp coming up in the next section and he's going to be great talking about tax cuts. No surprise there. What do you folks both think, starting with you, Stephen? What do you think would be the best news to come out of Washington? You're up in New York. What do you want to read in the "New York Times" tomorrow morning, the next morning, coming out of the Congress or the president in terms of turning the economy back around?

ROACH: Well, I think a tax cut would help. It's got to be more front loaded than back loaded. It's got to be directed at spenders, not savers. And…

MATTHEWS: So you want a Democrat tax cut?

ROACH: No, I don't want to label it, Chris.

MATTHEWS: I know you can't…

ROACH: I just would like, you know…

MATTHEWS: Well, what they want is an across-the-board sort of cash amount, a couple hundred bucks to every man, woman and child in the country, no matter if they don't even pay taxes, and they want it fast. Fast money. It's like everybody goes to their ATM machine and punches $200 and they get it. That's what they're basically offering. As opposed to the Republicans, who want to pay back people who've paid in themselves. The big taxpayers get back big tax cuts down the road. What's the better proposal here?

ROACH: Do we want, do we want, you know, structural reform of the tax system or do we want to jump start the economy? That's the decision we've got to make. Two different packages for two different problems. My guess is that an economy in recession needs a very different tax cut than the one that's working its way through Congress right now.

MATTHEWS: So you want the every man a king approach?

ROACH: Call it what you want. I think we need spending.

MATTHEWS: OK, let's go. What do you think, Tony, is that right? ATM machines, you punch $200, you get it back, everybody gets it?

PERKINS: Well, that would be a good start. But as I've argued, as you know, Chris, on this show, that the so-called rich people that the Democrats don't want to give their money back to are the investors, the angel investors, the venture people, the people who give the average guy coming off the street with an idea the chance to build his dream.

So I would just per se like to see a simpler, flatter tax for everybody. It would be great if we could all get a rebate. I know I just paid the biggest tax bill I've ever paid. I wouldn't mind having a few of those dollars back myself. But it's clearly all hands on deck time -- cut taxes, get the budget in order, cut interest rates, everybody's got to go back to work.

MATTHEWS: OK, we're going to have lower interest rates because Jack Kemp's going to call for them. The Fed may not deliver. Let me get to that question of the Federal Reserve, because all this talk about tax policy is so slow moving, fiscal policy is historically lagging in every regard in terms of getting things done.

The Federal Reserve chairman has been battling inflation. He's one of the most famous men in the world because he successfully battled inflation. Is he wrong-minded? Is he blind-sided? There we have him walking to work there at the Fed. Stephen, is he wrong-headed right now to be fighting inflation when there is none?

ROACH: He's won the war, Chris, so it's time to sort of face a different reality. We have just seen the greatest financial bubble in modern history pop. The Fed chairman, with all due respect, doesn't even admit that we had a financial bubble. Inflation is not the risk. Excess capacity and the aftershocks in the real economy are. He's got to take interest rates down a lot more than he's been doing.

MATTHEWS: Why is there no inflationary threat? Why is he wrong? Because there usually is. Why is there none now? Is it because of productivity as he or others have suggested? We don't face that threat?

ROACH: It has nothing to do with productivity. It just has to do with the globalization of capacity and the fact that demand is weakening well below the supply curve so no company has pricing leverage in this economy. Any cost pressures show up in reduced earnings or profit margins and that takes the stock market down.

MATTHEWS: OK.

ROACH: It's a different paradigm.

MATTHEWS: Tony, the prescription here is lower interest rates, a fast tax cut for everybody. You just pass out the money as fast as you can, a couple hundred bucks a person. Anything else? And free trade. And what else?

PERKINS: Well, again, I think there's a lot of pressure on the back of the John Chambers' of the world to just be humble, to understand that they lived in a period of excess. They countered a lot of revenues as permanent that were one time revenues. And so again, it's all hands on deck, got to run our businesses better and live up to…

MATTHEWS: How -- Tony, you know all these people. How does a person's lifestyle change when they realize they only own $500 million instead of $2 billion? How do they change their way of living? I'm curious.

PERKINS: Well, what we've seen in Silicon Valley is a lot of homes aren't getting built that thought they were going to get built. A lot of people are walking away from downpayments. A lot of people are selling their cars. I mean, again, it's back to reality. We all lived in the Internet distortion field and it was a fun lie, as the Grateful Dead would say. But we're back here in…

MATTHEWS: But remember the late '20s, we read about people jumping out of windows and lives changing dramatically for the worse? It doesn't sound like that's happening. It seems to me the losers here are the little people out there who invested in the stock market believing in the bubble, but the geniuses behind the bubble are doing OK. As I said, $2 billion down to $500 million ain't so bad, is it?

PERKINS: Well, that's true. When you really look at how the financial cycle works, the V.C.s and the guys that got in the earliest, as Stephen was referring to, and sold out, you know, some time before last August did real well. And so there's a lot of fat and happy people here. But a lot of people, like you said, small people that lost a lot of money on this hype.

MATTHEWS: I know. Thank you very much, Tony Perkins of Redherring.com. And thank you very much, Stephen Roach, for joining us tonight. Jack Kemp, he's coming up next. Wait till you hear his prescription. He's gung ho for big tax cuts now. And later, what's at stake as the U.S. and China prepare to meet? You're watching HARDBALL.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MATTHEWS: Welcome back. For more on the health of the economy, we're joined by Jack Kemp. He's director of Empower.org. Jack's group has just completed a study entitled "Tax Rate Reduction, The National Debt and Economic Growth."

OK, the executive summary, sir? What do you propose to do with this ailing economy right now?

JACK KEMP (R), FORMER VICE PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE/DIRECTOR, EMPOWER.ORG: Cut interest rates, cut tax rates and signal to the Fed through the White House, through the secretary of the treasury or the president, that Alan Greenspan has got to loosen up, that we're in the midst of a deflation, falling prices, falling gold price, falling commodity prices, falling stock prices. This is very serious and the Fed has to inject liquidity into the banking system and provide more oxygen for the economy.

MATTHEWS: OK, increase the money supply. How do you get taxes down now? It's now April. We're talking about a tax to be, a tax cut to be enacted in July or August. How do you make it rapid and important right now to the economy?

KEMP: Make it retroactive, as I believe President Bush wants to do, across-the-board rate reduction, retroactive to January 1 and cut the capital gains taxes Trent Lott and Jon Kyl want to do.

MATTHEWS: Yeah, but you can talk about that, but how legislatively do you do it? They've got a bill, it's moving through the Senate and the House now…

KEMP: When it goes to conference, make it retroactive. The conferees…

MATTHEWS: But there's no capital gains reduction in there.

KEMP: … between the Senate now -- they can put it in.

MATTHEWS: It's not in the scope.

KEMP: They can put it in or signal to the market that it's going to be the first bill after the passage of the tax cut.

MATTHEWS: OK, let's talk about this recession. We've had three recessions now in 20 years now. If I look at it, in 1981 we had one under Reagan when he first came in. And then on Bush one, George Bush's father, we had a recession in 1991 and '92. Here we are 10 years later, evenly, here it comes again…

KEMP: Yeah.

MATTHEWS: … 2001. What's caused these three recessions?

KEMP: Very…

MATTHEWS: Because we didn't have anything under Clinton.

KEMP: Very, very tight money.

MATTHEWS: How come it didn't affect Clinton?

KEMP: Because…

MATTHEWS: He had the biggest boom in history in the middle of these three Republican recessions.

KEMP: Yeah, yeah, because the Fed eased about 1992. The third quarter or fourth quarter of 1992, the last quarter of George Bush, Sr.'s term, the Fed began to ease. They brought the Fed funds, the overnight cost of money down, and that…

MATTHEWS: So Clinton's lucky?

KEMP: … coupled with the Republican Congress cutting the capital gains tax, passing Roth IRAs, tariff reform, lower tariffs is a tax cut. And what we're arguing in our white paper, and Empower.org is the sister research arm to Empower America…

MATTHEWS: Sure.

KEMP: … we're arguing that cutting tax rates in and of itself is not enough, that the Fed is too tight. They need to injustice liquidity into the banking system and provide more oxygen for the new economy and the old economy, which is suffering the sixth straight month of industrial production falling.

MATTHEWS: We've had, we've got a track record here. Why do we have recessions under Republicans, Reagan, Bush one and Bush two, and not under Bill Clinton?

KEMP: A good question. I think Republicans basically tend to be fiscal, fiscally tight and coupled with the Federal Reserve board being tight, you get a recession. I would make a case that our situation today, Chris, is not unlike that when Reagan came in in 1980. Volcker wanted to stop inflation and he crunched down on the economy and on, and raised interest rates. The Fed funds rate overnight cost of money went up to 11, 12, 13.

MATTHEWS: Sure, Volcker did that.

KEMP: The tax cut was stretched out by Stockman into '83, '84 and '5. So between '81 and '82 you had a huge deflation, the worst in this century, and that's what we're going through today.

MATTHEWS: I buy all that…

KEMP: Falling prices, falling commodity prices, falling gold price, falling industrial production, unemployment going up, no inflation whatsoever and the tax cut is not strong enough, although I'll give George W. Bush a lot of credit for pushing for an across-the-board Reagan like tax cut, it isn't strong enough when it's juxtaposed, when it's compared with the tight money of the Fed.

MATTHEWS: If we had had Ronald Reagan and we didn't have a 22nd Amendment, if we had Ronald Reagan for three terms, would we have had that recession 10 years ago?

KEMP: Oh, that's too hypothetical. In my opinion no.

MATTHEWS: If we had followed Reagan policies?

KEMP: If you remember, Reagan would, in my opinion, Reagan wouldn't have raised taxes. George Bush, Sr. and Jr. both recognize that that was a mistake. But right now the problem is not tax policy, albeit that is a problem, particularly two days after April 15th. Taxes are way too high, particularly on labor and capital. And…

MATTHEWS: OK, but you don't speak the same lines as…

KEMP: But right now we're in a deflation. The price of gold is falling…

MATTHEWS: You don't speak the same language as Alan Greenspan.

KEMP: No, I don't.

MATTHEWS: Alan Greenspan speaks Bill Clinton's language. Bill Clinton said I'm going to reduce the size of the deficit over time, I'm going to eliminate it over time and you're going to cut the interest rates. You're saying we're going to raise…

KEMP: He's raising interest.

MATTHEWS: We're going to cut taxes and we're going to keep cutting them, including the capital gains, and we want you to lower interest rates, and he says I don't hear you cause I don't believe in that.

KEMP: Well, he may not, but I think somebody's got to tell him that when you have a…

MATTHEWS: What do you got to do, how do you get rid of him? Alan Greenspan is here to stay, isn't he? You can't get rid of him.

KEMP: Yeah, you can get rid of him and I'm not about to call for his resignation. He's a friend and somebody that I have supported over the years and we have both supported many policies -- he wants to eliminate the capital gains tax.

MATTHEWS: Do you think smacking him around is going to get him to lower the interest rates?

KEMP: Jack Kemp smacking him around isn't going to do a thing. But I'm trying to get members of Congress to question monetary policy because basically there's three things that affect the economy -- fiscal policy, tax policy, traffic policy and monetary policy and Republicans, bless their hearts, I'm one, they don't talk about monetary policy and they let Alan Greenspan get away with saying two years ago that he was going to slow down the economy.

Now, unemployment is rising. How do you fight inflation by putting people out of work?

MATTHEWS: I get it.

KEMP: Where does it…

MATTHEWS: So the Republicans, just to shorten up here, the executive summary is you're for lower taxes, including lower capital gains…

KEMP: Lower tax rates.

MATTHEWS: Lower tax rates.

KEMP: Lower capital gains rates, eliminate the estate tax but…

MATTHEWS: And you like free trade. You like the free trade policies of this administration?

KEMP: Lower tariffs.

MATTHEWS: Lower tariffs.

KEMP: An across-the-board tariff reduction would be $2 trillion to the consumer over 10 years.

MATTHEWS: But you don't like this arm of the president around Alan Greenspan? They're a little too cute together. You think he should just stick it to him?

KEMP: I'm going to say something on your show that I, that is very provocative. I'm going to mention that four letter word, G-O-L-D. The price of gold falling over time is a signal, is a market signal that the Fed is too tight. I'll give you one quick example.

MATTHEWS: Right, because people buy gold when they see inflation coming?

KEMP: Absolutely. And they sell it when they need liquidity.

MATTHEWS: Right.

KEMP: Now, listen to this…

MATTHEWS: Let's come back.

KEMP: OK.

MATTHEWS: We're going to talk about China. We're going to talk about you and trade with China because it's a hot political issue. Are you a free trader or a cold warrior? Right back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MATTHEWS: We're back. Jack Kemp, you're the number one tax cutter in the country. You've been selling this since 1978, very effectively. Ronald Reagan bought it and he did very well. But let me ask you about this, right now, this new president, a Republican, Reaganesque guy wants to cut taxes and he may do something on capital gains down the road. He may get a 1.4 if you average it out between the House and the Senate, tax cut, a big tax cut.

You're saying with all that effort and all that good success legislatively, as long as we have Alan Greenspan in there fighting inflation it's not going to work, we're going to have a big recession?

KEMP: Well, if Greenspan continues to fight inflation when there is none, a $1.4 trillion tax cut aggregate over 10 years, 80 percent of which won't even happen until after the year 2005, won't make a tinker's damn of difference in this economy.

MATTHEWS: Has he got, is he a Chicken Little, Alan Greenspan? Why does he keep fighting a fire that isn't on, that isn't burning, inflation?

KEMP: That's the question I'm trying to get the Republican Congress to stand up and ask Alan Greenspan. He went up to Congress two weeks ago and all he talked about, and god bless him, talked about trade. But he didn't mention monetary policy and he said two years ago that it was irrational to be buying stock at a time when the economy was growing and he was going to slow down the economy to fight inflation.

He fought inflation to the point where unemployment is rising, industrial production is falling, Nasdaq is on its keister and we now have Cisco, NorTel, Lucent and giant telecoms starved for capital.

MATTHEWS: Would you invest in the market right now? You're a private citizen as well as a smart guy. Would you invest in the market right now or are you going into bonds or something like that?

KEMP: There are some very good buys. Selectively, yes.

MATTHEWS: Selectively. That's a very calculated statement. Anyway, thank you very much, Jack Kemp.

KEMP: Thank you, Chris.

MATTHEWS: Mr. Tax Cut. Jack's report on economic growth is available at his Web site, www.empower.org.

Up next, U.S. diplomats sit down with their Chinese officials, their counterparts. What's at stake in tomorrow's big meeting in Beijing? You're watching HARDBALL.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MATTHEWS: That 11-day standoff with China is over, obviously, but tomorrow in Beijing, eight American diplomats, including some military folk, are going to meet with their Chinese counterparts, including Chinese military people, to try and find out what went wrong and how to make sure it never happens again.

The two sides still blame each other, as we know, and the Chinese are holding onto that American EP-3 plane even now. The American team will try to win back the plane, but the Chinese want American spy planes, all the flights, called off their shores, wants them to end, period, an option the Bush administration has already taken off the table.

According to "The Washington Post," the Bush administration is considering other measures to ensure the flights continue, including sending the U.S.S. "Kitty Hawk," an aircraft carrier, to the South China Sea.

But some hardliners want the White House to go further and punish China for detaining those American air people. Punishment could include granting visas to prominent Taiwanese politicians, bulking up arms sales to Taiwan, including submarines, anti-sub planes, and Kidd-class destroyers, limiting military-to-military contact, cutting off exchange programs, imposing limits on technology transfers, opposing Beijing's bid to host the 19 -- the year 2008 Olympics, and delaying approval of satellite launches.

If satellite launches are delayed, American companies are like Loral stand to lose big. Loral says it could lose up to $180 million if a deal to launch a satellite falls through with China.

One area that doesn't seem to be on the bargaining table tomorrow is trade. A senior official tells "The Washington Post" the Bush administration is unlikely to seek limits on trade with China.

With me to discuss tomorrow's meeting in Beijing and what's at stake for both sides is Congressman Duncan Hunter, he's a Republican from California, a member of the Armed Services Committee. And out in Kansas City, Congressman David Dreier, he's also a California Republican.

Let's go to Duncan Hunter, congressman from California, should we punish China?

REP. DUNCAN HUNTER (R-CA), ARMED SERVICES COMMITTEE: Well, I don't think it's so much punishment, Chris, as looking at the big picture. And what we're doing with trade right now is sending an $80 billion-per-year surplus into the Chinese treasury, and they're using a lot of those billions to buy military equipment, primarily from Russia, like the Sovremennyy-class missile destroyers they bought last year.

And they're aiming a lot of that military hardware at the United States, and we've now discovered in this incident of the last week or two that China appears to still have some hostility to the United States, and also has a foreign policy which at some point, with respect to Taiwan, may come into a clash with the United States military.

So the question to us is, should we as Americans be funding with American trade dollars the building of a military machine in China that our soldiers and sailors may one day face on the battlefield? And I think that's a real question, a long-term question, that the Bush administration must ask itself.

MATTHEWS: Congressman, what do you think would be the reaction in the Chinese streets, I mean, among the people, the young students, the intellectuals, the people that do follow the news, to the word that we have dropped trade with them and cut them off from our huge consumer market in this country? What do you think would be the reaction from the Chinese people?

HUNTER: Well, I don't know how they would react, but I know this. The hard dollars that they didn't used to have, for example, when they tried to buy these Sovremennyy-class missile destroyers in the early '90s, which were designed to kill American aircraft carriers by Russian technicians, they had the Sunburn missile, they're very effective, they're tough for our ships to handle, when they tried to do that and they had no cash, they couldn't do it.

Today they have cash, and the cash comes from the United States of America.

MATTHEWS: Let's go, let's to go Congressman David Dreier. What do you think would be the reaction from the Chinese people if we tried to isolate them economically at this point in their rebounding history?

REP. DAVID DREIER (R), CALIFORNIA: Well, Chris, Duncan and I are like brothers. We came to Congress together two decades ago, and I consider him to be one of my best friends. But he is dead wrong on this. The single most powerful force for positive change in the 5,000-year history of Chinese civilization has been economic reform. Those dollars about which he refers go from the United States to China. And you know what it's done? It's dramatically improved the standard of living for people throughout China.

We need to make sure that we do everything that we possibly can to continue down that road. And why would we consider withdrawing the one good thing that is there? That's why, as you went through that litany of issues, I'm so happy that this administration has made what I believe to be the right decision, and that is taking trade off the table.

I just returned from Asia. I was in Japan and in Hong Kong last week. And it was a very emotional experience. I was on Okinawa at Kadena Air Base, where I met with the squadron commander of the EP-3 crew that was over there. And it was -- we are all so proud of George Bush, who did an extraordinary job in dealing with this tough situation, Chris.

It seems to me what we need to do is, we need to recognize that we've gotten strong presidential leadership. We've resolved a tough issue. And this meeting which is taking place in Beijing is a very important one. We need to remain very strong. We need to maintain our military preeminence in Asia. It's a very, very key…

MATTHEWS: Any difference would you advocate…

DREIER: … thing for us.

MATTHEWS: … congressman, would you advocate any nuance of difference, given what happened in the last couple weeks or without that happening, between the Bush policy and the Clinton policy?

DREIER: Well, very clearly, President Bush has described the relationship as being one of strategic competition, as opposed to a strategic partner. Now, you can be friendly with your competitor. I made a very strong statement when I was meeting with the leadership in Hong Kong about Gao Zhan, who is the woman from Virginia who we very much want to have returned.

I also spoke very strongly about the fact that we've seen improvement over the years, but we have a ways to go.

So this administration, as I believe, following a tack which is correct, it's right on target. Sure, it's slightly different from the Clinton administration. But remember, Bill Clinton, when he ran for president, was virulently opposed to any kind of trade with China, and he finally embraced what I believe is the appropriate position. And that helps us right here in the United States.

MATTHEWS: Congressman, I want to run through these…

DREIER: You know, and these consumer products that come in…

MATTHEWS: … I want to (UNINTELLIGIBLE) this issue, this menu of issues that's come up in "The Washington Post." They've got a good reporter, I think, at the Pentagon. Should we continue the arms? Should we go with the arms sales of the Kidd-class destroyer to Taiwan? Should we try to stop them from getting the Olympics in 19 -- in the year 2008? Should we stop satellite launches with our technical assistance and knowhow? Where would you cut through that and say, This we should screw them with, this we should deny them, this we should leave alone?

HUNTER: Well, well, Chris, first, I don't believe in these symbolic efforts, like not going to the Olympics or trying to do something that simply slaps the other party in the face. I think what we have to do is substantive. And you know, the debate that we're having right now that David, my good friend and I, are having is one that we had in 1939 and 1940 with respect to the Japanese. We had a number of American industrialists said, Let's keep selling steel to the Japanese, we're engaging, we're bringing them around. They're going to work with us.

And yet, and yet in 1941, we saw that steel being transformed into warships which attacked us at Pearl Harbor. So…

MATTHEWS: Well, wait a minute…

HUNTER: … if you have this…

MATTHEWS: … congressman, there's another point…

HUNTER: … and Japan, and Japan turned…

MATTHEWS: … here.

HUNTER: … on China. Exactly. And Japan turned on…

(CROSSTALK)

MATTHEWS: … whatever the A, B, C, D…

HUNTER: … China, that's the thing we need to recognize.

MATTHEWS: … embargo on oil that drove the Japanese to Pearl Harbor when the Americans that ducked the Canadians and we all basically said, You're not going to get any more oil, and your little country doesn't have any oil, they broke out, didn't they? Couldn't you look at it that way, starkly?

HUNTER: Well, well, well, Chris, if you look at it that way, then what we're doing is putting ourselves in even a more precarious position, because you're saying now, we're prisoners to $80 billion trade surpluses going the other way. And if that doesn't happen, somehow we're going to be vulnerable. And to an…

DREIER: Duncan, if you want to go…

HUNTER: … to an aggressive Chinese foreign policy…

DREIER: … Duncan, if you want to back to -- Duncan, if you want to go back to…

HUNTER: My point is, David, David, you want to…

DREIER: … go back to 1939…

HUNTER: … you -- David, you want to watch those kids come in, and you told, you told me how much you care about those kids. My point is, if you really care about those kids in the Navy, you don't want to transfer technology and dollars that are buying technology from people like the Russians that one day may kill those kids…

DREIER: It's a…

HUNTER: … on the battlefield.

DREIER: It's a -- it's improving the…

HUNTER: You don't agree with that, do you?

DREIER: … quality of life -- Let me just tell you something. People like to draw an allusion. The difference between the Soviet Union and China is a very distinct one. If you want to talk about…

(CROSSTALK)

HUNTER: … class missile destroyers…

DREIER: … 1939 -- it -- let me just…

HUNTER: … aren't an illusion, David.

DREIER: Duncan, Duncan…

(CROSSTALK)

HUNTER: … missile destroyers…

DREIER: … Duncan, I'm not talking…

HUNTER: … through the straits of Taiwan…

(CROSSTALK)

DREIER: … I didn't say an ill -- I didn't say an illusion, I said an allusion. And the fact is, what we need to do is realize that it was the protectionist policies that the United States pursued in the 1930s that strengthened Adolf Hitler in Germany. And we need to realize that in this global economy…

MATTHEWS: How did that work, congressman?

DREIER: … if we're going to improve the quality of life for the people in China -- How did it work?

MATTHEWS: Yes.

DREIER: The protectionist policies that we as a nation pursued during the -- the Smoot-Hawley…

(CROSSTALK)

DREIER: … disengaged the United States…

HUNTER: There you have it, Chris, it was…

DREIER: … of America from Europe…

HUNTER: There you have it, Chris, it was protectionist…

DREIER: … disengaged…

HUNTER: … policies that caused that collision out there off the Hainan Island, protectionist policies.

MATTHEWS: OK, let me…

(CROSSTALK)

DREIER: No, no, no, absolutely not. No, we were doing that -- Duncan, we were doing the absolute right thing. And I support strongly the surveillance flights, the continuance of those. And we need to do everything that we can. And I'm glad that President Bush has taken that off the table. We're doing it legally, we're doing it appropriately.

All I'm saying is that if we choose to pull up the drawbridge and not expand our Western values into repressive societies like China's, we are going to undermine the prospect for positive change.

MATTHEWS: Let me ask you, Congressman Duncan Hunter…

HUNTER: How many American corporations complained, David, about the incident off Hainan Island? I don't think any of them complained. They continued to…

DREIER: Duncan, Duncan, Duncan…

HUNTER: … 50-cent-an-hour labor…

DREIER: … let me just tell you…

HUNTER: … and that's what they…

DREIER: Let me just tell you something.

MATTHEWS: OK…

DREIER: I talked to one of the top industrialists…

(CROSSTALK)

HUNTER: … any time you want to.

DREIER: … in this country…

MATTHEWS: OK, let me, let me ask you both a question.

HUNTER: Sure.

DREIER: Well, let me just tell you, though, let -- Chris…

MATTHEWS: One thing that we've learned in this whole episode is that there is Chinese public opinion. It's a dictatorship to a large extent. It is not a democratic society. But there is sentiment in the streets of China, especially among young newspaper-reading TV-watching Chinese. They're very nationalistic. They are not communists, but they're extremely nationalistic.

Is it smart U.S. policy, Congressman Hunter, to try to further aggravate that nationalism with some kind of revenge, whether it's cutting off trade at this point or whatever?

HUNTER: Well, first, Chris, I think we can have a good relationship with China without moving an $80 billion-per-year trade surplus their way, and without sending militarily critical technology into their military base like the supercomputers that we've transferred in the past under the Clinton administration. So I think even this administration, as free trade as it is, is going to want to look at some mechanisms to slow down the transfer of militarily critical technology that one day could kill young Americans on the battlefield…

(CROSSTALK)

DREIER: … I totally agree with that.

HUNTER: … reversing that trading…

DREIER: I totally agree with that.

MATTHEWS: OK, let me ask you both, simple question. Should we kill those satellite launches that are being put up there with the help of Loral?

HUNTER: I think so. I think that the hearings that we held in the Armed Services Committee showed that we gave a lot of technology that ultimately is used in ICBMs, the same ICBM boosters…

MATTHEWS: Right, and the Democrats…

HUNTER: … that are aimed at American cities…

MATTHEWS: … got a million bucks for that too.

HUNTER: … booster satellites.

MATTHEWS: And the Bill Clinton and the Democrats got a million bucks for that transfer of knowhow. What do you think, Congressman Dreier, should they -- we allow those…

DREIER: I think this…

MATTHEWS: … launches? Go ahead.

DREIER: … I think this is a decision that we want to leave to the administration, and I happen to believe that we need to do everything that we can to try and expand getting information in, but not technology which can be used militarily against us. When there's access to information and technology from other parts of the world, we shouldn't undermine the United States on this.

And let me just say, top industrialists who are involved with China were outraged with the shooting down of our plane and so…

MATTHEWS: OK.

DREIER: … or the -- our plane being knocked out of the sky…

MATTHEWS: Thank you…

DREIER: … so don't claim that they're not…

(CROSSTALK)

MATTHEWS: … thank you, the two gentlemen…

HUNTER: … how President Bush handled this.

MATTHEWS: … the two warring gentlemen from California, both Republicans, both in the same party, both from the same state, the same region of the state, believe it or not, they disagree.

Just a reminder, coming up tomorrow on HARDBALL, national security adviser Condoleezza Rice joins us, Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts, and Don Hewitt of "60 Minutes," all here on HARDBALL tomorrow night. Also Tom Friedman of "The New York Times," what a night we got coming tomorrow night here on HARDBALL. Stay with us for tonight.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MATTHEWS: Well, we have two wings of the ideological world of America. We got Katrina Vanden Heuvel joining us from "The Nation" magazine. She's the editor of that magazine. And from "The Wall Street Journal" editorial page, John Fund, one of the strongest voices on that very conservative page.

Let's take a look at the latest numbers. According to the latest Gallup poll, pretty good number here, 60 percent of the American people think Bush, the new president, is doing a good job keeping America prosperous. Only 30 percent say he's doing a poor job. Katrina, what is that about? Why do they like Bush two to one?

KATRINA VANDEN HEUVEL, EDITOR, "THE NATION": Well, I keep thinking of another poll, Chris, which came out just a couple weeks ago, which showed 60 percent of Americans believe Bush was favoring corporations, protecting them, over ordinary Americans.

You know, your program before was about this tax cut. I mean, let's expose the cynical lie of Bush's tax cut. It is not for ordinary Americans. It is that -- it is front -- it is back-loaded in a way that isn't going to help the faltering economy, which is heading into the tanker, and, you know, what you really need is what a lot of Democrats have been talking about, the progressive caucus, which is a prosperity dividend. Let's give $500 rebate to low-income, middle-income…

(CROSSTALK)

VANDEN HEUVEL: … workers so you get it to people immediately. And that way you're going to help a faltering economy and help displaced workers.

MATTHEWS: You really think, though, that the Democrats would be pushing tax cuts even of this sort of ATM, go to your local machine and pick up $200 no matter who you are, which is sort of the approach everybody's talking about on the Democratic side, would they be pushing any tax cuts, Katrina, if the Republicans under President Bush hadn't been pushing them first?

Democrats don't usually come out for tax cuts, do they?

VANDEN HEUVEL: Well, you know…

MATTHEWS: Think of that, I can't think of the last time they did.

VANDEN HEUVEL: Well…

MATTHEWS: When's the last time Democrats pushed tax cuts?

VANDEN HEUVEL: But, but you're right, but the problem with…

MATTHEWS: I mean, tell me the last time Democrats pushed a tax cut. Give me, give me the year.

VANDEN HEUVEL: I don't know, because…

MATTHEWS: Well, give me the year!

VANDEN HEUVEL: Well, you know, I want to say maybe 25 years ago. But the problem with the Clinton economic program was that it was Calvin Coolidge-like. It was pay down the debt, pay down the debt, instead of what this debate should be about right now, which is not about accounting and this $1.6 trillion folly, it's about the unmet needs and priorities of this country. That's what this should be about.

And that's why…

MATTHEWS: Well, John Fund, let's bring you in here on the tax cutting. I just don't know any track record of Democrats to claim they're for tax cuts unless the Republicans push them first. You have to go back to Jack Kennedy, clearly, back in the early '60s, as far as I can remember.

Go ahead.

JOHN FUND, "THE WALL STREET JOURNAL": Well, it's a lost tradition. I'm glad Katrina mentioned my favorite president, Calvin Coolidge, because he cut taxes, and that's how he reduced the debt. Revenues went up. So I really don't think that Katrina has a leg to stand on there.

As for corporations, Katrina, Americans have a balanced view of corporations. They suspect corporate power, but they also know corporations create jobs. And I'll agree with you, yes, the Bush tax plan in its original form was back-loaded. But now we're going to front-load it. We're going to add a lot more incentives so that they kick in earlier, Republican add-in retroactivity, so it will…

MATTHEWS: When are we getting the first tax cut? When's the average person watching television…

VANDEN HEUVEL: Exactly…

MATTHEWS: … right now, John, going to get a buck back extra from the government?

VANDEN HEUVEL: In about six years…

FUND: No, because it's retroactive. You're going to see it the day it's passed, because it's going to be made retroactive. You'll see deductions from people's paychecks.

VANDEN HEUVEL: But the, but the larger problem, John, is that there is a lie underlying this budget and this tax plan. It is skewed to the rich, at the same time as the Republicans are screwing middle-income, low-income Americans by pretending that this tax cut is going to help them.

FUND: Katrina, the…

VANDEN HEUVEL: Listen, the people in the abstract don't like government. But when you ask them about government and health care and education and in their lives, they care. And two-thirds of Americans…

MATTHEWS: I agree with that.

VANDEN HEUVEL: … did not put the tax cut…

MATTHEWS: Katrina, once again…

VANDEN HEUVEL: … as a priority.

MATTHEWS: … you have tight (UNINTELLIGIBLE). I agree with you. We're right back with Katrina, because she's got a very good point about the environment. I think the tree-hugger argument over the environment never wins. I think the public health argument wins. We'll be right back to talk about the environment as a political issue, meaning cancer. Right back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MATTHEWS: Let's talk political strategy, even though people here disagree, Katrina Vanden Heuvel of "The Nation" magazine and John Fund of "The Wall Street Journal."

I want to start with you, John. It seems to me the -- that the idea -- that the people on the environmental side of the fight with industry always make the fight long term. It's going to affect the environment later on down the road with global warming, it's going to cause the extinction of some endangered species, for example, which will affect us ultimately.

But the short-term impact the bad environment, of a bad environment is cancer. If you've got dioxins, arsenic, things like that in the water, things getting into our food we eat, the fat we eat from meat and things like that, and getting into the air, not just cigarette smoke but industrial -- pollutions, pollutants, it seems to me that's a better way to address this issue, because it matters to individual families, all of whom who have cancer in their family.

FUND: Absolutely, but it should be based on sound science, not junk science. You know, Michael Kinsley, a card-carrying liberal, admitted in "The Washington Post" last Friday that Bush was right on the arsenic standard. I've talked to career people of EPA and Interior who say…

MATTHEWS: Why do you all of a sudden trust somebody like Kinsley?

FUND: Because it's…

MATTHEWS: Who you always disagree with?

FUND: … I don't -- no, because he backs up what the scientists say. I'm simply saying even a liberal can look at the facts and come to the right conclusion. Chris, these career people of EPA and Interior admit that the Clinton administration set a booby-trap for the Bush administration. They purposely put in midnight regulations that they knew were unworkable, the Bush people would have to…

MATTHEWS: So they were pandering…

FUND: … walk back from.

MATTHEWS: … to the environmentalists' lobby but they weren't doing anything that would work, OK, I understand. Katrina…

FUND: Well, no, no, because, because they knew the Bush people would have to repeal them. Therefore they would take the hit politically.

MATTHEWS: Do you see what I'm trying to say here, Katrina, that the average person is cared -- cares about the health of their family first and foremost…

VANDEN HEUVEL: Absolutely.

MATTHEWS: … and if you can address this issue to them, you got a winner, whereas if you talk long term, the environmentalists keep losing these arguments. I don't know, maybe they haven't, but…

VANDEN HEUVEL: Well, as I said before, I think when you talk about government in the abstract, you lose many people. When you talk about what government does and has done over decades, when you talk about, to a family, and say that there may be more arsenic in their kids' water, you are talking about a president who may become viewed, as someone said, as the Great Contaminator. He wanted to be the Great Communicator. But he has done what not many people could do, which is unite an environmental community.

This is not junk science. There is grounded science here around many of these issues…

MATTHEWS: If it's, if it's serious…

VANDEN HEUVEL: … and if there is a payback here, if there is payback, if there's a Green payback, it is clearly that this is the most pro-corporate, pro-oil, pro-gas…

MATTHEWS: But Clinton didn't do it till the last minute he was in office, why -- if it was such a good thing to do, why didn't he do it…

VANDEN HEUVEL: He did many…

MATTHEWS: … in '93?

VANDEN HEUVEL: I am not defending the Clinton administration. I'm saying there was a lot of work to be done under the Clinton administration which wasn't done. What is going on now, though, is an unprecedented rollback. It is a staggering list of pro-corporate paybacks. And John, don't give me the stuff about how I'm against corporations. There is a high road corporations should take, and that should engage taking care of families and people and putting those people first, not profits, in this country.

FUND: I never said you were against corporations. People are legitimately suspicious of corporate power. But they need to have a balanced view. Katrina…

VANDEN HEUVEL: I'm balanced.

FUND: … these Clinton, these Clinton regulations would not have kicked in until 2008. If there is a clear and present cancer danger on arsenic, I think we would have seen the regulations kick in a little bit sooner.

The bottom line is, if you read the National Academy of Sciences report, it says there are no clear studies which show that link. Therefore, the Clinton people were just doing this for political purposes because they knew the Bush people would have to repeal them…

(CROSSTALK)

VANDEN HEUVEL: … but John, you know, but John…

MATTHEWS: … I got to interrupt, I've got one last topic. And Katrina, you get to lead the ball. The ball goes to you. One of the smartest, toughest people in Hollywood, one of the greatest singers probably ever, certainly up there with Sinatra, is Barbra Streisand, whether you like her politics or not. She wants to see a cable network formed which will basically offer a liberal point of view the way that I can think of one other network that gives the conservative point of view.

Do you think it would make it economically, and would it have an audience?

VANDEN HEUVEL: Well, first of all, my unders -- the met -- my understanding is that Barbra Streisand spoke realistically about how the Democrats should be far more aggressive. She's very -- you know, she -- she understands the cost now of this network and how, how -- that we should have been working on this decades ago. It's not too late. There's digital television, there's satellite television. But the costs, I think, have led her to understand the lack of feasibility.

But there are many other things that people of conscience, like Barbra Streisand, could do to energize the progressive base in this country.

MATTHEWS: Fund, respond, John.

FUND: There is a liberal feminist network out there. It's called Oxygen Media, and we all know how well it's doing. Clinton's former deputy White House counsel works there. Chris, what Barbra really said is, We want to get rid of these GOP talking heads. Well, the problem is…

(CROSSTALK)

MATTHEWS: … radio people too, like Limbaugh…

FUND: Well, but…

MATTHEWS: … especially, I think, and G. Gordon Liddy…

FUND: Well…

MATTHEWS: … and Ollie North and people like that on radio.

FUND: But the problem is, on television there's almost always balance. There's one liberal versus one conservative. So what she's really like, what she's really saying is, she doesn't like the debate because her side loses it.

MATTHEWS: Well, I would like to know why -- and this is a fact -- why there's so many more conservatives who want to listen to political debate than liberals. And I don't quite know the answer. Do you know, Katrina?

VANDEN HEUVEL: I don't think that's the case. I think that these satellite digital programs, progressive left programs, have a fanatical following. But I do believe that the way the FCC's…

MATTHEWS: OK.

VANDEN HEUVEL: … moving, the media's moving, we are having a conservative landscape…

VANDEN HEUVEL: … depoliticize these people.

MATTHEWS: … next time. Thank you very much, Katrina Vanden Heuvel, the -- of "The Nation" and John Fund of "The Wall Street Journal." You get all the political buzz here any time on e-mail, hardball.msnbc.com. We'll be right back. You're watching HARDBALL.

See you then.

urn:contentItem:5XY1-F9G1-DY7P-T05F-00000-00Invitation to Ivanka Trump draws backlash at big tech show2020-01-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:55ZLexisNexisWORLD NEWSPg. 1Invitation to Ivanka Trump draws backlash at big tech showSteven Clarke

Consumer Electronics Show or CES 2020 had officially started its event on January 7, and although the event is still ongoing until January 10, a lot of tech fans on Twitter already expressed their dismay towards CES after Ivanka Trump- the first daughter of U.S, President Donald Trump- appeared and talked about technology on the said event. "We are committed to providing all Americans with pathways to great careers through skills training and vocational education".

For the most part, though, she stuck to safe topics, speaking of the administration's commitment to helping the formerly incarcerated secure work in the technology sector upon release by teaching them programming and other IT skills.

"We need to raise awareness about many options that exist", she said.

"I'm a big believer in innovation and the positive impact productivity has on economy, and fighting for American dominance in the industry". Thank you for creating an enabling environment by thinking about the regulations and eliminating redundant regulations that do not achieve the desired goals, but "we need more workers and we are not willing to invest (in training) ".

Trump also said that there was no better time to be employed in America, but much has been said about how Americans are overworked and underpaid.

Trump appeared alongside Gary Shapiro, president and CEO of the CTA, inLas Vegas to describe how the USA government is trying to work with private sector leaders.

It is not clear how Trump found her way onto the CES agenda-whether the Consumer Tech Association, which puts on the show, or the White House made the request.

Trump, 38, also commissioned the board to develop what she called an interoperable learning record.

Haka at Australian volunteer firefighter's funeral

Andrew considered his greatest achievement his 19-month-old daughter Charlotte, Mr O'Dwyer said, who he loved madly along with his wife Melissa.

"It's not only about training for the jobs of the future", said Trump in her speech.

The Trump administration has a list of policies that want the human resources departments of companies across the country "to make sure they are not inadvertently selecting qualified applicants for jobs that now have vacancies". "The keynote that I'll be doing with Ivanka Trump will be focusing on. how industry is working with government on this very important issue", he said.

She also spoke about her focus on workforce development in relation to her work as presidential adviser and how she acts as co-chair of the National Council for the American Worker alongside commerce secretary Wilbur Ross. Trump referred to robotics and autonomous vehicles and how they can help in areas such as truck driving. "We need to recruit and retain the world's greatest talent to help us grow and innovate, but we need to invest in American workers and get to the background". "So, I think wait until you hear what she has to say and listen to it because the fact is that there is afocus on jobs".

Creative Strategies principal analystCarolina Milanesi blasted the choice of Ms Trump as a voice for female entrepreneurs, questioning her experience in the technology industry.

Before the keynote took place, many were confused and frustrated as to why Trump was given a place at the trade show, partly because of her status as a representative of an administration with policies many find distasteful, but also because her place could have been taken by a woman more connected to the technology sector and better suited to speak about how innovation will change the employment landscape of the United States and the world.

Brianna Wu, a video game developer who is running for Congress in MA, tweeted before the event decrying the decision to give Trump a platform over other women working in tech. "I don't think it's unfair to believe that Trump didn't stop and think if she was the best woman for the job before accepting the CTA invitation".

No stranger to such criticism - CTA was called to task previous year for having a paucity of female speakers at CES 2019 - the organization defended its choice, touting Trump's work on initiatives ranging from paid parental leave to funding for historically black colleges.

Update, 5:52 p.m. Add more quotes.
