Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:58GG-WJY1-JCMN-Y1XJ-00000-00In-Vitro Journalists — Never Having to Show Up and Report the News2013-05-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:55ZLexisNexisIn-Vitro Journalists — Never Having to Show Up and Report the News

May 22, 2013 (Dissident Voice:http://www.dissidentvoice.org Delivered by Newstex)
We Don't Argue Like That On F-U- Book
Can you call it a harangue when the entire mess of human survival is at stake? Usually, the school and the yard are tied to the continuous fight to empower youth to push away the structures, strictures and sanctities of the corporate imperative to turn every human being on earth into a data point, all anchored to digital money, digital actualization and their new hierarchy of needs around the economic growth imperative of an endless conveyor belt of more and more junk technology turning us into more than mere addicts to their stuff.


We are becoming the stuff . . . the junk!
Now, education is bought, sold, packaged, constructed and manipulated into a conveyor of profit motive loving administrators, the infinite pigs of private (corporate welfare state) capital and venture funds who have their fat mitts into the public troughs. It's pervasive, the agnotology and outright stupidity of the common man, that is, you and I. I talk with twenty-somethings, and some in their thirties, and they just more than genuflect at the alter of the Kindle, the junk pop culture crap on TV or cable and the endless quest to just cobble together one crappy job with the next four.
Just today, working with Portland liberals (culturally, pro-pot, pro-same sex marriage, pro-bike, pro-solar panel, pro-eggplant), even they have no clue about the US Postal Service: 'Oh, half the stuff is junk mail. The sooner they can get cut back, the better off the earth will be.' 'Oh, they are billions in the red, and the taxpayer will have to pay that to keep them going.' 'Oh, the union is too demanding, too much they want.' 'Oh, I can't wait till all our mail is delivered by email!' Not a clue about labor, collective bargaining, why it is a bit odd they are getting $10 and $14 an hour to take care of some pretty intensive cases of Developmentally Disabled Adults in group homes. All the training in critical response, first aid, behavior science, intervention, physical restraining, psychology, and all the re-certifications and mandatory workshops and classes, yet, Ten Bucks an Hour? No benefits? I am still amazed at how effective bad media, rotten press, endless cultural crap, all the music and digital zombie stuff infects youth. How youth still think the US of Empire is the Best in the West, and how all the other countries have it so-so much worse.
Medium Well Done Is the Message
I still am amazed at how bifurcated the world is, and how rotten at the top things are - NPR's Zionist and hyper-East Coast Whiny Crap Everyone's a Woody Allen-Jon Stewart-Barbara Walters clone or variation on a theme has infected them, and so has the droll of Huffington Post, and the barrage of the fabulous frivolous fakery of a music-art-food-theater-movie scene within a scene. Poly-amorous, Poly-historical, Poly-philosophical, Poly-capitalist, Poly-consumerist.
The time now is the message, and the medium is the madness in their minds. Anything goes, as long as it's on a smart screen, i-Screen, Google Search, their own personal dozen blogs. How do you feel, America? China? Vietnam? Stupid pet-child-boyfriend-boss-blender-voyeur trick. This is the generation of peeping Toms, hyper distracted, disengaged, connected, flippant, urbane, casino capitalism. They actually think the Arab Spring was Twitter, and that there is an Arab Spring. Really? Which Spring is that?
The absurdity of their own society high centered on the spine of the whale of corporation x, y or z. They doubt that Apple is Doing Wrong with Tax Evasions, and they think multiculturalism is Big Tech Getting More Exploited Immigrant Workers Vis-a-vis the H1-B Visas - 180,000 more a year, thanks to redneck Orin Hatch and compliant Democrats.
They actually believe that Amazon dot Com is a bastion of democracy, creativity, the future, and oh so NOT Wal-mart! More ways to screw the American worker and the temporary migrant worker lured to the USA for that next big thing to screw humanity High Tech In-NO-vation, well, they think that's the price of collateral damage.
They trust companies and guys like Branson of Virgin to solve climate change, and they think that there are so many downers in the world and on that progressive radio, 'that there's no use fretting about it all . . . have a hand-crafted mead or hoppy pilsner.'
New Hierarchy of Social Media Needs 
We are becoming genetically-wrapped to a new Maslovian chart of human needs, wants and actualization. It's definitely not tied to any holistic, community-driven and human centered needs to make sure young and old, poor and disabled, and those without education and skills get the largess of our effort to make sure the world is a place that can survive WITH us. Because of US. For US.
Without belaboring the point, we have no choice but to drive all relationships and human and cultural endeavors around the FIVE e's of sustainability, all connected, all tied to an umbrella or superstructure around e-for education and e-for equity. With those two e's - Education and Equity - we will have the BIG e-for-environment covered. Those other e's - economy and energy - will then be put into a grander perspective and scaled toward the needs of 7 billion of us, or 9 billion creatures that we are, as we then develop a higher need of existence opposite to using nature as resource mine and dump and deforming culture around computerization and robotics/mechanization.
It's nauseating - this brave new world of computing, err, work. So, the revolution will not be televised, nor will it be digitized. It's not going to be a resurgence in human rights, labor empowerment and community power through Tumblr or Yahoo or Fake-Book.
This big lie of collective consciousness and public good will not unfold through the labyrinth of digital unreality. Each and every moment of this massive Handmaid's Tale of Digital Computing adds to the end of Homo Sapiens, or any morphing away from any semblance of a human with agency.
The Consumer Species — Weather Makers, DNA Warp Drive, Engineered Thinking!
We are Consumopithecus Anthropocene, living the lie of self-actualization and global connectedness in each and every corporate move toward seamless corporate access to our personal financing, biographies, lusts, loves and lamentations. Our bio-psychological-social states have been invented for us, smoothed and sculpted from the soft clay of corporate control.
This hour has passed long ago when we have been able to leave behind our skins for a new skin. We are now in the silicon hands and microprocessor wombs of an infinite army of voyeurs, data collectors, men and women with unscrupulous power to invent more ways to move humanity toward extinction. We are the blood, sweat and tears of the new meaty ATMs of the Corporate Herding Networks.
Communities are frayed, and Facebook and Amazon and Flicker and DARPA and DOD and Homeland Security vis-a-vis USAPATRIOT Act have squeezed the last breath of creative resistance and solidified revolution from the very fiber of our Hominid souls.
We went through several million years of evolution as the walking species to be transformed into the marketing species . . . the ever-dumbdowning sub-species of simian whose goal is to find a smorgasbord of things to sell and buy. The mummies of the future, super-sized and big-gulped into HFCS wax figures, all preserved with Round-up Ready formulas and mercury tinted skin.
On-line Obedience will continue to fray and immolate any chance of young and old to get off their keyboard-tapping asses to actually do something in the real. Cybernetics as emancipation my ass.
The new speak is computer engagement, programming literacy, IT culture. These corporations are now dictating even what non-profits do. Even lowly organizations that are in existence to just feed the poor are marionette-ed by High Tech. All of us have to be programmers, web designers, flash movie inventors, and social media mavens to make it in the world of even social and environmental justice cause organizations.
I can't teach English or writing anymore, without including 'setting up your own web site . . . blog . . . please turn in all essays with embedded links, videos, sound, colors, scratch and sniff biometrics . . . incredible ticker-tape motions.' The message is only the medium/multi-media/hidden codes.
Bye-Bye Middle/Any Class — Pig Hearts, In-vitro Burgers, Petri-Dish Journalists
It's absurd, really, that WE have to be all they want us to be when it comes to these captains of dig-i-tal-industry who blather on about how the education system is worthless because we are not producing their quotient of digital (computer programming language) multilingual software manipulators ready to force humanity to evolve into a nano-atomized scrolling, screen-fused thing that ponders endlessly the unending barrage of the meaningless, all that vapid data that could change the gravity of Saturn if it could be downloaded through the rings.
We've allowed this endless barrage of the worthless and meaningless junk on the web to infect our every waking and sleeping lives. It's the constant bottom and top screen running headline news blathering nothingness and the naughty and necrophilia and nihilism of social misfits that we now all aspire to.
Give me Tweets and Coffee House Banter and where did you get that cool pair of pants conversations. I'm not just talking about the creeps at Google and the creepier ones catapulting their version of humanity through the slipstream of instant flash movie, streaming video, quadraphonic sound through the bi-speckles of their future. Google Glasses filming of each individual's meaningless life, while walking, through sleep, shitting, sitting, snoozing and sneering. One unbroken stitched- together digital history of the meaningless meanderings of Consumopithecus Anthropocene contemplating silly cat tricks and the insipid lukewarm gesticulations of a mind morphed into data collection, Instagrams, Drop-boxes and cloud servers.
Xenotransplantation? Nano-tech engines coasting through bloodstreams? RFID chips implanted in every human born[1]?
Fake meat and Google Glasses. It's called In Vitro Meat IVM. We are so screwed! Look at this pap on Huffington Post -
We know how to make the meat. All it takes is a biopsy of muscle cells from a living cow, chicken…whatever…called myoblasts. The cells are then grown in a nutrient-rich culture medium that delivers them all the goods that they would get in vivo-that is, if they were still inside the animal.
But that's not all. They also have to grow on an edible scaffolding which would allow them to organize into 3-D muscle fibers that can stretch and bend. Essentially, they need to be able to exercise like traditional muscle, because of course, that's what meat is. Lots of labs are working on this, and the miniscule meat bits that they have been able to produce so far are kind of grey and flavorless.
But that's what happens when you grow a thin sheet of muscle cells all by themselves. The holy grail of in vitro meat will be to make a product that simulates the complexity of muscle in a living animal. Truth is, that's probably not in the cards just yet. The first available in vitro meat will likely be a combination of muscle fibers, fat cells (for flavor) and blood vessels (for color and iron). They'll be grown separately and then mixed together. But I honestly don't see that being a problem. As Americans, we're kind of okay with the chicken nugget and hot dog culture we've grown to know and love.
More[2]:
Just read these putzes, and you understand how that a dozen blogs in every house mentality is just self-replicating stupidity[3]!
Dang Duy Minh Quan, 1st Year student, Bachelor of Business Management, Lee Kong Chian School of Business, Singapore Management University
Executive Summary
This paper provides an analysis of in-vitro meat and its viability as a meat substitute in the future. The paper will do so by first explaining the production process and history in order to set the context. The paper will then move on to discuss the potential economic, social and environmental impacts if in-vitro meat were to be successfully implemented. We will also address the challenges faced in commercial implementation of in-vitro meat and discuss the various issues surrounding this controversial new technology.
The paper will conclude with the author's evaluation on where in-vitro meat will stand in the future.
Introduction
Food prices are rising. The total cost of conventional meat farming will continue to increase proportionately with the demand for meat due to exponential world population growth. In 2008, 18.5 billion animals are killed for food in the U.S alone, according to the U.S Department of Agriculture (USDA, 2008). And for that many animals to be raised, a whole lot of water, grain and grass are required. This means that the meat industry is putting an enormous strain on the environment.
They just never ever ask the right questions, make the right propositions, or understand the bigger picture around their consumer, artificial lies theses. Sometimes it's just difficult to begin to respond to the inanities. New book out by T. Colin Campbell - Whole.

Nice review by a reader here: **[4]
T. Colin Campbell follows up his groundbreaking book 'The China Study' that examined the impact of nutrition on cancer with 'Whole: Rethinking the Science of Nutrition' which explains why there has been so much resistance by our health care system and government to examine nutrition's impact on our health. Campbell gives an overview of his research and the reasons why his work continues to be challenged. He provides insight into the medical community, pharmaceutical industry, supplement industry, media and government. He backs up his ideas and statements with examples and research making this book a rich source of information (much like 'The China Study') that everyone should read. Since his first book is such a large reason why this book was written I would recommend reading 'The China Study' before this book, but you don't have to read that book before this one to understand the issues. When I finished reading this book I was disgusted and discouraged by our health care system and inspired to do what I can to change it. I highly recommend this book to everyone because American's can't afford to ignore this research.
Appeal Notes (May contain spoilers):
Genre: Non-fiction, health, nutrition
Pacing: Slow, academic
Tone: Scholarly, disheartening, inspirational
Writing Style: Descriptive
Comments: This book is a must read for every American. Campbell's research and insights can not be brushed aside or ignored much longer. Even if you don't want to have anything to do with a plant-based diet you should be aware of how our healthcare system is operating (or not operating).
These Zionists Love Control . . . Obama . . . Rand Paul . . . Orin Hatch
Artificial meat, artificial thinking, artificial reality? All these guys and gals are the enemy, really. Hyperactive brains, hyperactive egos, hyperactive bank accounts, hyperactive dis-associative diseases! Glass? Trademarked by Google. Can I ever use the word 'glass' without paying Google a royalty[5]? ­Ahh, a pair of glasses by Google, that grand lying company working on Completely Computerized Self-Driving Automobiles! Hyperactive Terrorists. Against humankind. Terror through the streets. Zombie growers!
Google Glass isn't even for sale yet, but it's already facing backlash. There have been articles in the Atlantic and Wired mocking techies who have a pair, and even Saturday Night Live got in on the jabbing at the technology. The New York Times ran a front-page story about Google Glass and privacy, and the gadget has been banned from a bar in Seattle and casinos in Las Vegas.
But for the earnest Googlers who helped create Glass, and the enthusiastic techies who already have their hands on a pair, all this hate can be a little bewildering. Most of the people I've talked to who have the fancy eyewear just love them. 'Just taking a hike on a Sunday, I've been blown away by taking pictures and taking video,' said Javier Echeverria.
Mary Lambert got cooking instructions using Glass. 'The friend who I was doing it with could see what I was doing and was like 'No no no, that's all wrong,' which was really helpful and I didn't expect it,' she says.
Right now, Google Glass might be the world's worst spy camera; if you go out in public with a pair on, you are guaranteed to attract attention. Still, the idea of techies mounting a tiny screen and a little camera to their faces makes millions of people uncomfortable.
You even hear about these these 'magnificent' museum tours, sans human docents and dedicated and passionate museum staff, with these smart glasses that will be piping in music, video, some razzle-dazzle actor type blathering on and on about this or that feature.
Wow, take granddad to Normandy Beach with Google glasses and let the flash video and layers of digital entertainment download while he hobbles on the beach where he lost 5,000 comrades. Megabyte and gigabyte memories, invented by those whiz kids with the programming prowess and endless dead sea thinking, that somehow, jobs are best done through microprocessors and video and sound cards.
What a day - all those bombs, those 19,000 civilians, the visceral grit of war, replicated, digitized in unlimited variations of visuals, trivia games, film-spun encyclopedic facts, even the heat of bombs and acrid lung-sapping stench of burning flesh and diesel choreographed for the last World War Two veteran. Shifting social norms? ­
'They realize that Google Glass will require shifting social norms to be accepted.' In that regard, the past few weeks have been rough for Google. If the company is going to turn around the public's impression of this product, it will need some help — from people like Sarah Hill.
Hill is a storyteller for the Veterans United Network and a volunteer for Veterans Virtual Tours. She wants to use Google Glass to take World War II vets on virtual tours of places they might be too old or frail to visit in person. 'Places like the World War II memorial, Arlington National Cemetery [or] Pearl Harbor even,' she says.
Hill is convinced that leading a virtual tour for veterans while wearing Google Glass would be completely different for them than showing the group just a DVD. She says it gives them the ability to ask questions and request certain sights and sounds, like the waves on the beaches of Normandy or the waterfalls at the World War II memorial.
Little (and many) Eichmanns — Digital Wunderkinds Are Looking for YOU!
Wow, what a day to look forward. Heil Programmer, Heil Apple, Heil High Tech. So, it goes without saying that another loser of the high stakes and rich kind of game - with plenty of bully pulpit support in the form of NPR, Bloomberg and Wall Street Journal fawning - is me, educator, and my dedicated brethren fighting to KEEP Humanities, Classics, History, and All the Meaningful Disciplines Worth Seating a Culture (yep, not IT, knowledge worker bs, economic 101 or post-Hedge Fund Version 3.0).
These guys are not the great ones in this or the past generation, and their goals are tied to hucksterism - creating more and more layers of digital technology and digital communications, and all these little offshoots of junk, data points, endless flash videos and digital story books.
They are in the business of selling billionth of a second ad space in the new world of wasteland web 4.0.
Here is what one of the big names in High Tech has to say to recent graduates. The reason I started this column today in the first place:
Dear college graduates: The next month is going to be thrilling as you cross this major milestone in your education. Enjoy the pomp and circumstance, the congratulations, and the parties. But when it's all over and you're ready to go out into the world, you'd probably like to meet me, or others like me—I'm your next potential dream boss. I run a cool, rapidly growing company in the digital field, where the work is interesting and rewarding.
But I've got to be honest about some unfortunate news: I'm probably not going to hire you. In part, it's not your fault.
If you grew up and went to school in the United States, you were educated in a system that has eight times as many high-school football teams as high schools that teach advanced placement computer-science classes.
Things are hardly better in the universities. According to one recent report, in the next decade American colleges will mint 40,000 graduates with a bachelor's degree in computer science, though the U.S. economy is slated to create 120,000 computing jobs that require such degrees. You don't have to be a math major to do the math: That's three times as many jobs as we have people qualified to fill them.
Unless you understand the fundamentals of what engineers and programmers do, unless you're familiar enough with the principles and machinations of coding to know how the back end of the business works, any answer you give is a guess and therefore probably wrong. Even if your dream job is in marketing or sales or another department seemingly unrelated to programming, I'm not going to hire you unless you can at least understand the basic way my company works.
And I'm not alone. If you want a job in media, technology or a related field, make learning basic computer language your goal this summer. There are plenty of services—some free and others affordable—that will set you on your way. Teach yourself just enough of the grammar and the logic of computer languages to be able to see the big picture. Get acquainted with APIs. Dabble in a bit of Python. For most employers, that would be more than enough. Once you can claim familiarity with at least two programming languages, start sending out those resumes.
So congratulations again on your achievement—and good luck getting your real-world education.
Kirk McDonald, president of PubMatic, an ad tech company in Manhattan. Previously, he was president of digital for Time Inc. What a loser![6]
Autistic . . . On the Spectrum . . . Asperger's? We Have Cubicles for YOU!
Yes, real world is virtual world. The real world is maximizing profits, manipulating percentages, figuring how to sell time and space and human exhales and inhales. These people are the ones we have to fear - autism and untapped labor, err, exploitation and money-making market!
­White-Collar Careers [7]
One Fortune 500 company that has begun hiring people with intellectual disabilities in North Texas is Alliance Data. Jim Pierce, vice president of Corporate Administration, says 'this is an untapped labor market.'
He has hired a dozen people with intellectual disabilities.
'We've got this one guy, for example; his productivity is three times as productive as the person doing his job who did not have cognitive disabilities before him. And his error rate is 2 percent. He is 98 percent accurate. He's a phenomenal worker,' Pierce says.
Pierce thinks it won't be long before more companies realize they're missing out on a hiring opportunity. In the meantime, nonPareil is trying to keep up with growing demand for training and jobs in Texas. It's looking to build more campuses in Fort Worth, and eventually in Silicon Valley, Calif.
And the NPR, NBC, Junk TV, Dead End Tabloid News, Slick News-Zine 'beat' goes on!
More Coming — All Those Books Written by the ONE Percent!
We'll look at more of the High-Stakes, High-Minded, Whoopee Creative Class's look at how high tech kills US. These following people are are far from cutting edge, far from descent, far from holistic and concerned folk. They, of course, are the One Percent, and their perspectives are as skewed as Donald Trump's or George Soros', but we shall look at their theses in upcoming School Yard Fights, since the fight is about privatization, single thinking common core bs, and the digitizing of K12 and higher education, to the detriment of society, people, workers, labor, climate change mitigation, and an end to EMPIRE and NEOLIBERALISM.
Jaron Lanier
This week sees the publication of 'Who Owns the Future?,'[8] which digs into technology, economics and culture in unconventional ways.
Much of the book looks at the way Internet technology threatens to destroy the middle class by first eroding employment and job security, along with various 'levees' that give the economic middle stability. I paste the titles below from Alternet, another Zionist organization that is pushing the One Percent and 19 Percent's bs controlled opposition yammering. Note that the links at ALTERNET are Amazon dot kill! Get your local library to purchase any of these books, or do an inter-library loan. Speak to people there, at your public library, and ask them not to use Amazon. Why?
Here:**[9] Really, here! We at DV have put out tons on Amazon, which is an evil company, evil-Zionist Trader, the Big Bald Guy Who Wants Charter Schools, Who Wants All Internet Sales, Who Wants Authors at the Foot of His Throne!
Evgeny Morozov
'To Save Everything, Click Here: The Folly of Technological Solutionism'[10]
Nicholas Carr
The Shallows'[11]
Robert Levine's
'Free Ride'[12]
Lanier's
'You Are Not a Gadget.'[13]
Poison-Fluoride Loses Big
News Flas[14]h — Portland just voted out any proposal for fluoride - poison — flushed into our drinking water. The fourth time we voted that proposal down. Portland, the largest city in the country that does not have this industrial poison pumped into the water. The pro-fluoride folk — lobby and goofy dental associations — spent big bucks on propaganda, and some families cancelled out votes for and against, but in the end, bye-bye more toxins in our water. Water that already is stressed by industrial pollutants, industrial farming, radioactive isotopes and drought!
Measure 26-151 lost by a resounding 3-2 margin, the fourth time in five tries that Portland voters have turned down the idea of fluoridating the city's water supply.
'At a very fundamental level, people understand that we don't want more chemicals in our water,' said Kim Kaminsky, leader of Clean Water Portland, at a campaign party for fluoride opponents at the On Deck sports bar.
The nonprofit Upstream Public Health brought the idea of fluoridating Portland's water to city councilors last year, quietly building majority support on the council before the public really caught wind the fluoride issue was back on track in Portland.
The council unanimously approved fluoridating Portland's water last September, but the stealth campaign by supporters may have backfired.
Fluoridation opponents, with little money or professional political help, quickly gathered enough signatures to force a public referendum on Tuesday. 'In 30 days, we put together an operation to gather 43,000 signatures,' said Rick North, a member of Clean Water Portland's steering committee.
Portland is the last major city in the U.S. without fluoridated water, and, now that voters have spoken, will remain so.
Ahh, E-D-U-C-A-T-I-O-N versus PROPAGANDA.
Education wins!
Community Action wins!
Counter-Intuitive Thinking wins!
Critical Thinking wins!
Crowd Funding Everything
We shall get into this soon in another School Yard Fights, but basically, now college researchers, chemists, what have you, are doing this on-line crap of crowd funding for projects. Can you believe that? Washington State University professor and scientist wants to see the effects of coal trains coming from the Powder River Basin to Washington to our export terminals, where that dirty coal will be shipped to India and China!
Not that the coal companies have to pay and do the research on the effects of coal dust on communities. Nope! We have reached that stage in this f-ing country where we the community have to figure out the negative effects of a corporation's business model and actions on US, the community.
So we go begging for dollars, again, thanks to the digital disgust of the IT kind. This is way sick beyond any decent level. Read how the Seattle Times misses key questions!
'There is no scientific research or study, or even anecdotal evidence, that coal dust from trains has ever negatively impacted a community in Washington,' BNSF Railway wrote the government in January[15].
'So we don't even want to know?' Jaffe asks. 'Why not look?'
Feeling stymied, Jaffe is trying an end-around. He's going straight to you to fund his coal-train study.
He has launched a 'crowdfunding' proposal[16] at a Seattle-based science-fundraising site called 'Microryza[17].'
Two former UW researchers started it last year after they became disillusioned with the way science is funded (or often, not).
Can't get your research backed by the usual government and corporate suspects? Then take it to the streets.
Do you get the picture? Something is wrong but consistent here. Corporations are more than just people. They are the government, the regulators, the writers of laws, and the voice of communities. Seattle Times writers are as colonized as young kids with their iPhones.
The Un-Education of these Reporters. Might as Well be Crowd Sourced Journalism!
What's fascinating about Jaffe's experiment is that big industrial developments like coal terminals have long been able to limit official study of their projects.
Their argument here is that it isn't fair to review things that happen along the existing rail lines, or after the coal is shipped overseas.
The government should study changes at the loading-dock site only, not the regional or even global implications of shipping coal.
Legally, that may be right. But the Web makes this framework moot. There's now little stopping a determined scientist from going rogue — from studying whatever he or she wants and submitting the results straight to the court of public opinion.
Assuming the public will bankroll it first.
I'm sure this won't go over well with the powers that be. It sounds like democracy and the free market in action to me.
Danny Westneat's column [18]appears Wednesday and Sunday. Reach him at 206-464-2086 or moc.semitelttaesnull@taentsewd
A future column. Really. I'll get to it. After the other thirteen DOZEN!

urn:contentItem:5VFR-D8K1-JB20-G4H4-00000-00Invoking the 25th Amendment; New Bill To Tax Tech Giants; Hamilton's National Anthem2019-02-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:55ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTLee Carter, Jon Hilsenrath, Jonas Max Ferris, Clint McDonald, A.J. Louderback, Tom KlozaNEWSFinancial021802cb.231Invoking the 25th Amendment; New Bill To Tax Tech Giants; Hamilton's National AnthemCharles Payne, Andrew McCarthy, Lauren Simonetti, Jonas Ferris, Jared Max, Cheryl Casone

CHARLES PAYNE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning.

I'm Charles Payne, in for Maria Bartiromo.

It's Monday, February 18th. Your top stories at 7:00 a.m. Eastern time.

Another border battle heating up. Democrats vowing to fight against the national emergency call by President Trump over border wall funding.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. KEVIN MCCARTHY (R-CA), HOUSE MINORITY LEADER: The President, one, has the authority. Yes, it is a crisis and emergency our the border.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: In this case, I think the President overreached. I think this is a constitutional issue. I think it's an important issue. And I do think it sets up a precedent for many reasons.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

PAYNE: Tens of thousands of people are set to protest the national emergency declaration. We're going to hear from law enforcement officials on what they're seeing at the border.

U.S. markets are closed today for the Presidents Day holiday. Futures relatively flat all morning. This after the major indices posted big gains on Friday. The Nasdaq composite leaving bear market territory along the way.

And checking on the global markets action in Europe, somewhat mixed -- CAC 40 is up.

Asian markets though higher -- China leading the way there in anticipation of positive talks this week.

Crude oil -- crude oil surging, the price of oil hitting the highest level of 2019. We're looking at what's actually driving that market.

And Payless closing -- the retailer closing all of its stores after filing for bankruptcy.

Plus, a tax on big tech. Tech giants Google and Facebook among those being targeted for bigger taxes and oversight.

And a messy finish, Denny Hamlin winning the Daytona 500 yesterday but it wasn't a pretty race with one crash right toward the very end claiming 21 cars. Highlights and much more coming up in sports.

And here to help break it all down -- pollster and Maslansky and Partners president Lee Carter; Wall Street Journal's global economics editor Jon Hilsenrath; and MaxFunds.com's co-founder Jonas Max Ferris.

All right, guys -- a lot of big things coming up here. Tomorrow's Walmart's earnings. We've got the China trade talks this week. A lot of things coming up.

JON HILSENRATH, GLOBAL ECONOMICS EDITOR, "THE WALL STREET JOURNAL": I think the Walmart earnings -- you referred to this earlier -- I think it's really important. You know, the economic data have been very strange and mixed over the last few weeks. We had a gang busters jobs report and then we turn around and get this total flop of a retail sales report. The manufacturing numbers have been up and down.

I think we have to look at some of these company earnings to try to get a sense of whether this economy is cooling down a lot more than people expected.

PAYNE: Well, you know, there's no better proxy for at least, you know -- for the heartland, the brick and mortar area, you know. And the third quarter data, the $124 billion in three months. And of course, the fourth quarter is going to be more than that. The question though is what the guidance is going be.

HILSENRATH: That retail sales report last week just didn't line up with what retailers have been saying.

PAYNE: Of course not.

HILSENRATH: Retail numbers haven't been that bad.

PAYNE: Internet sales down 3.9 percent. Come on -- give me a break. Department store sales down 3.3 percent, maybe. We can live with that, we can understand that. But out of like 11, 12 categories only two were higher, right.

So you're right. It's not exactly what we're seeing -- and we're not seeing that in the market at all.

JONAS MAX FERRIS, FOUNDER, MAXFUNDS.COM: Maybe, the Commerce Department employees were angry about not getting paid, they're like I'm just --

(CROSSTALKING)

PAYNE: They missed a few keystrokes --

FERRIS: Internet sales were whatever I said they were.

But Walmart, you know, normally Walmart I think would be a better indicator. But besides the fact they have problems with a lot of their items are under tariffs essentially, that has pressure problems.

But then you have blooms (ph) like basically you have a store like Payless goes out of business. That business -- a lot of that is going to Walmart on some level.

PAYNE: Toys R Us -- a lot of that business goes to Walmart.

FERRIS: Yes. Like they should be benefitting. On the other hand, they got a lot of pressure from Amazon. So like there's so much going on that I think it's hard to say, oh yes, it's like a normal -- like 50 years you go back, the consumers fine, Walmart sales are up. I think there's just too much going on in that business right now to make a call.

PAYNE: All right. We'll leave it there.

Coming up this morning OPIS chief oil analyst Tom Kloza is with us; former federal prosecutor and Fox News contributor Andrew McCarthy; former California congressman and U.S. Trade and Development Agency head nominee Darrell Issa; and former chief of staff under Bill Clinton and McLarty Associates chairman Mack McLarty. You do not want to miss this all-star lineup.

Also our top story of the hour -- border funding showdown. A wave of protests are being planned across the United States for Presidents Day. This in response to President Trump's national emergency declaration. Democrats vowing to fight back with some already planning lawsuits.

On "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES", Maria Bartiromo spoke with House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy who says the President was right in declaring an emergency.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Is this a national emergency? Your reaction to what's happening with the President saying that it's a national emergency, but some of your colleagues are pushing back.

MCCARTHY: Yes, it is a crisis and emergency along our border. First of all think about the human trafficking that is happening --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCCARTHY: -- think about the children that are being moved across this country. But think about the amount of drugs and how many thousands of Americans are dying and most of that is coming through the southern border.

Yes, it is an emergency that has been shown before. And I believe at the end of the day this wall is going to be built, not sea to shining sea, but about 200 miles.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

PAYNE: Joining me now -- Jackson CountyTexas Sheriff A.J. Louderback and retired sheriff and executive director of the Texas and Southwestern Border Sheriffs' Coalition, Clint McDonald. Gentlemen -- thanks for joining us.

M1: Thank you.

CLINT MCDONALD, EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR, TEXAS AND SOUTHWESTERN BORDER SHERIFFS' COALITION: Good morning.

PAYNE: Clint -- let me start with you, the media joining in with Democrats essentially saying this is a crisis made up only in the mind of President Trump. There is no crisis.

Entries -- illegal entries are down, apprehensions are down and that this is much ado about nothing. What do you think?

MCDONALD: Well, as I represent 31 sheriffs along the southern border of the United States with Mexico, I can tell you that we've been fighting this battle as a group since 2005.

It is not just about the issue of right or wrong. It's also the collateral damage that is causing these individual counties and the expense of this illegal traffic coming through our counties. And so its collateral damage is sometimes devastating for some of the smaller counties as to what they're having to face in monetary expense to those borders being open.

PAYNE: A.J. -- you met with President Trump at the White House last month. How have you seen this administration's work on the security of our southern border? Do you think they're heading down the right path.

A.J. LOUDERBACK, JACKSON COUNTY TEXAS SHERIFF: Clearly a superb job by the administration. Let me reiterate what Clint is talking about here. Border sheriffs, Texas sheriffs, every sheriff in this nation are fighting the effects of the southern border.

We've been crying for decades for something to be done about this. It's time now. Clearly, it is a major issue for us in law enforcement in this country.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY AND PARTNERS: So gentlemen -- a lot of the opposition to the wall and to secure borders is that this is inhumane. That this is a humanitarian issue, that we're not treating people fairly. Can you tell me how you react to that?

MCDONALD: Well, I can tell you as a retired sheriff and working on the border for the last 34 years that humanitarian crisis that we see is we do not want to get another call to have to go and pick up a body of someone who is trying to get across these borderlands and is deceased. That is a call not one of our 31 sheriffs ever want to get again.

So when we look at the inconvenience of maybe families being taken apart or that -- that is a humanitarian issue, but to go and pick up a body that -- no sheriff wants to do that.

PAYNE: Yes. There's no doubt about that. What do you make of the notion though that this issue has been resolving itself? There was some misleading headlines on Friday saying that last year was the lowest in apprehensions.

That was actually fiscal year '17. Fiscal year '18 saw a 17 percent jump. And so, again, when you have the media putting out a narrative, gentlemen, that this is something that was working itself out, that it is not a crisis -- how do you articulate to the public that yes, indeed, this is something that by the way serves both sides of the border -- Americans and those who seek to come here illegally.

LOUDERBACK: Well, Charles -- exactly that. And you have a tremendous amount of misinformation, outright deceit about what's going on here. There's no working this border situation out unless we were able to put the barriers that we need, the infrastructure that we need to regain operational control of a border that we haven't had for decades.

This is a long-time problem that Texas sheriffs and other sheriffs in this country have been representing. The simple idea that we have to fight over national security is, for law enforcement officers, professional law enforcement officers in this country, is ridiculous.

PAYNE: Well, gentlemen -- I want to say first and foremost thank you for your service -- Sheriffs Clint McDonald and A.J. Louderback. And we appreciate you, people who work this, who have seen the damage, the carnage, the pain and suffering, to share those stories with us -- thank you very much.

PAYNE: Coming up, oil in focus, Brent crude on track for its strongest first quarter in eight years. We're going to break it down what's driving these gains.

Plus, a wild crash -- Denny Hamlin winning the Daytona 500 yesterday but it just wasn't a pretty race. One crash near the very end taking out 21 cars in the running. All of the sports highlights later on this hour.

PAYNE: Oil in focus, Brent Oil slipping this morning but still on track for its strongest first quarter since 2011. This coming as investors remain hopeful over supply cuts and global trade talks.

Joining me now, chief oil analyst with OPIS -- Tom Kloza. Tom -- thanks for joining us.

TOM KLOZA, CHIEF OIL ANALYST, OPIS: Good to be here.

PAYNE: Oil has been whipped around like crazy in the last year or so. And just as you think it's going to break out, it collapses and just as you think the collapse is going to continue, it finds a way to rebound. What's driving all of this?

KLOZA: Well, I think first of all, you have to recognize that it got over- sold tremendously in December. I mean, there was no reason for WTI to get down to about $40 and Brent to get down to about $50.

And then you did have OPEC really coming in with cuts and they are for the moment over-complying, at least the Saudis are. You know, they're complying to the tune of 120 percent of the cuts.

Now, don't expect that at the end of this year we're going to see a quarter like the first quarter and subsequent quarters. There's only so far we can go. And U.S. production will probably surpass 12 million barrels a day this morning. It was five million barrels a day back in 2011.

And I think world demand is going to slow a little bit. You know, most of the forecasts have been at 1.5 million, 1.6 million barrels a day because of emerging market growth. That will probably pull back a little bit.

So we think it's going to be a cheaper year than last year but a lot more expensive than what we saw at the end of December of 2018.

FERRIS: Tom -- Jonas Ferris here. Is any of this responsible -- I keep thinking like peak car, I keep seeing numbers like with Uber and everything. Millennials don't want to buy cars -- like does that have any role at all in this relatively low oil price? Everybody five, ten years ago was thinking $100 was the new normal in oil. And it seems barely able to stay over $50. Or is it really just what's going on with OPEC and Russia and global demand?

KLOZA: We've seen car sales really tail off and they particularly tailed off in China in 2018. I don't think we're at peak car. But you know, there's going to be a point here probably this coming decade where we'll be peak internal combustion engine car.

And we're going to be competing with electrons -- there's no question about that. Whether that happens in 2028 or 2030, I'm not sure.

But, you know, we're about 101 million barrels a day right now in terms of demand. That's not going to grow at the pace that it grew at in the last 10 or 20 years and it's basically because you've got billions and billions of dollars that are going into electric vehicles. And you've got some great strides that are being made with battery prices.

HILSENRATH: Tom -- oil prices drop in the fourth quarter was a sign that the global economy was slowing down. Now that we see prices firming up, what is that telling us about the global growth backdrop? Are things firming up out there?

KLOZA: Well, I think prices dropped probably on the premise that we were already in a recession and we were headed to recession and I think people have backed off from that. I think the economy couldn't, you know, keep up its sort of just incredibly robust pace.

But it is something to watch, you know. Gasoline consumption in the United States can be a real, real leader of what the marketplace is doing.

Right now, it's ok. It's about where it's been the last few years. But there aren't many things that can catalyze it.

The President is going to have a difficult time with gas prices this year. He's going to see prices go up in the spring as they normally do and we'll probably get to about $2.70 a gallon or so.

And he's got the two levers. He's got the lever with the sanctions on Venezuela and the sanctions on Iran. And a little bit too much pushing on one lever could send prices a little bit too high. And he's made it clear, he likes low gasoline prices, he likes to take credit for low gasoline prices. And he recognizes that that's a big thing for his base.

PAYNE: Tom -- about four or five years ago, ExxonMobil wrote this amazing piece. It was maybe a hundred pages. And essentially what it boiled down to was they guaranteed that they would be able to sell every ounce of oil that they have in-ground right now by the end of time. In other words, all of these wars that we hear against fossil fuels, against gasoline, against crude oil, that they will never truly impact what we have in terms of supply. Do you agree with that?

KLOZA: Well, I think they've changed their tune to a certain extent. There will be a peak demand period. That peak demand is probably at least 10 or 20 years off.

The interesting thing is what really has helped Exxon Mobil, and has helped a lot of the companies in the United States, is the export market. There's going to be weeks in 2019 where we're going to be exporting five million barrels a day of crude oil.

Now, compare that to 2015 or even early 2016 when there was an export ban and you could not export anything. So we are going to be a bigger exporter in the world than everyone but Saudi Arabia and Russia. We're going to surpass Iraq, Iran -- you name it. And it's going to happen quick.

PAYNE: Tom. Tom Kloza -- thank you very much. Really appreciate it.

KLOZA: Thanks -- guys.

MCCABE: Discussion of the 25th Amendment was simply, Rod raised the issue and discussed it with me in the context of thinking about how many other cabinet officials might support such an effort.

REP. JOHN RATCLIFFE (R), TEXAS: As a conspiracy starts to unravel, sometimes the co-conspirators turn on one another and you get inconsistent testimony. McCabe's testimony is also inconsistent with Rod Rosenstein.

PAYNE: Joining us now, Former Federal Prosecutor and FOX News Contributor, Andrew McCarthy. Andrew, you saw the interview. You saw the news leading up to it. What do you come out of it thinking?

ANDREW MCCARTHY, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Well, I think the biggest take- away, Charles, is that they tried to insert Russia as the reason for McCabe, opening an investigation on Trump. My own belief, by the way, is that they had been investigating Trump all along.

The only thing that happened in May of 2017 is they went overt in their files on what they had been doing for months before that. But what they were very careful in the interview, not to do, was to say what it was about Russia that Trump wanted, for example, Rod Rosenstein to put in his memorandum, removing Comey, and what it was precisely about Russia that Trump was worried about at the time.

They just kept saying Russia, Russia, Russia. What was actually going on was, Comey, in public testimony, had suggested that the President was a suspect in the investigation. Privately, Comey had been assuring the President that he was not a suspect.

And what Trump wanted was for Comey to say publicly or at least it to be known publicly, what he was being told privately, which was that the President was not a suspect in the investigation. That was the aspect of Russia that he wanted publicized.

PAYNE: Now, you wrote a piece last week titled, McCabe, Rosenstein and the real truth about the 25th Amendment coup attempt. In it, you said that the conversation to remove the President was no joke, but of course, the idea was lunacy.

Rosenstein, in that interview, it seemed to say -- not Rosenstein, I'm sorry, McCabe, suggesting that, no, there was no joking about any of this stuff, from wearing a wire to the 25th Amendment.

MCCARTHY: Yes, I think, Charles, that McCabe was quite right about that. Rosenstein didn't, you know, idly come by and make a few jokes about the 25th Amendment. What they were talking about at the time was, is there a way to remove this president.

And if you talk about invoking the 25th Amendment, what that involves is gathering together enough of the cabinet to, at least, raise the issue with the vice president and try to invoke it. McCabe and Rosenstein themselves were not in a position to invoke it.

And one way you would try to generate that kind of support would be to generate evidence about it, which is obviously why Rosenstein suggested wearing a wire, in hopes of catching the President on tape, saying something that was either crazy, that suggested that he was not up to the job, that he was corrupt or what have you.

PAYNE: Right.

MCCARTHY: But that was the whole idea. The idea of recording him was in order to fortify this idea of the 25th Amendment, which I think they quickly dismissed because they knew there was no prayer, number one, that they could get enough support for that. And number two, the 25th Amendment is really not for the situation that they were dealing with.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: So, I watched the interview and I was looking at it, you can look at it two ways, right? You could look at it and say it's completely damning of the president, say this is absolutely one of the worst things that he was -- you know, that he's nuts and that he needs to be out of office, if you watch it one way.

You could watch it another way and say, I've got a lot of questions about McCabe, sounds like there was a lot of chaos, that's very believable. But, when there's chaos, you might have these kinds of conversations. Can we pull the 25th Amendment? Can we get him out of office? I'm so frustrated, the whole thing's nuts. But you could have a lot of questions.

And when you watch this as an attorney or prosecutor, what questions did you have or what did you take away from the interview?

MCCARTHY: My big thing was why doesn't he ask him what it was about Russia that Trump wanted in the report that -- or the memo that Rosenstein wrote, what they said in the conversation was that Trump told Rosenstein that he wanted Russia in the memo, removing Comey.

And it seemed to me that Lester Holt -- it wasn't Lester Holt, I guess it was 60 Minutes last night.

PAYNE: Scott Pelley.

MCCARTHY: Scott Pelley. What Pelley should have asked him at that point was, what was it about Russia that he wanted Rosenstein to say? Instead, they just left it out there that it was Russia that sounds really sinister. But if you go back in time to what happened, Trump obviously wanted Rosenstein to say that Comey had told him on three occasions that he was not a suspect in the Russia investigation.

And we're not speculating about that. We know that because the President, on top of the memo that Rosenstein did, put a cover letter, in which he made sure that everybody knew that Comey had told him three times he wasn't a suspect.

PAYNE: Andrew, this is now being called -- I've seen some call this a political coup attempt, perhaps, a bureaucratic coup attempt, a soft coup attempt. Does this rise up to some form of coup? Was there the idea that the FBI, because they were upset with the outcome of this election, using Russia as an excuse, where he wanted to try to find a way to remove the President of the United States?

MCCARTHY: Yes. These guys, Charles, were definitely coup-minded in May of 2017, but I think this is a much bigger trajectory. It goes back many months and I don't think there's any question that they were trying to make a case on President Trump, even as they were telling him he was not a suspect in the investigation.

PAYNE: Andrew McCarthy, thank you very much, really appreciate it.

MCCARTHY: Thank you, sir.

So, officials estimate that the value in New England of all of those services, are worth in U.S. dollars, so it's clearer for us, $1.9 billion. A tax on that would be $55 million going to the government. The Prime Minister says this is a way that big companies pay their fair share.

So I started looking at the share that companies pay and here's Facebook, as an example. Tax year 2016, they paid taxes, $43,261 on an estimated $100 million in revenue. Are you ready for the tax rate? 0.04 percent, it's not just New Zealand, several countries in Europe and Australia, also considering digital services taxes.

The worry is, this is the flip side, that businesses bolt, they leave. Let's stick with Facebook and let's stick with the United Kingdom right now because they have a message for that company. Regulation is coming. There's a scathing new report out, it's from the House of Commons, and it concludes that Facebook violated data privacy laws repeatedly and knowingly.

JON HILSENRATH, GLOBAL ECONOMICS EDITOR, WALL STREET JOURNAL: What about attacks? What about attacks on their revenue? Is that -- you know, what's striking to me is that, you know, that would have been unheard of 10 or 20 years ago, and now it's gaining steam.

JONAS FERRIS, FOX NEWS ECONOMIC ANALYST: Yes, I mean, this is a regulatory issue about all the stuff they pulled and the digital gangsters. I mean, there's the no one's paying any tax side of the story, which has nothing to do with them.

PAYNE: The OECD is actually working on that right now, so that, you know - - you've got them trying to actually -- all of these major countries are actually working together on how to put together a tax regime that these big companies can't escape.

urn:contentItem:3X4K-B9H0-00MP-T1W5-00000-00In Wake of Witching, Big-Caps Reverse Their Course1998-03-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:55ZLexisNexisMARKETS; Market RoundupIn Wake of Witching, Big-Caps Reverse Their CourseBy , Senior Markets WriterMarch 23, 1998 6:17 PM ET

Confused by that unfamiliar red color on your screen's Dow Jones Industrial Average quote? Do not be alarmed. It indicates a decline, which is something blue-chips used to do back in olden times. 

In classic post-triple-witching fashion, the Dow and the broad S&P 500 followed up their big Friday run-up with a retreat. The witch, Wall Street's nickname for the simultaneous expiration of futures, stock options and index options, brings with it volatile swings in equity trading. The Monday after a triple-witching Friday usually runs counter to the previous session's trend, and today was no exception. 

The Dow and the S&P were underwater throughout the morning and early afternoon, but from about 1 p.m. EST to 3:15 those indices enjoyed an uptrend that put the S&P briefly in the plus column. Then a wave of program-driven selling hit the market and knocked the indices down, with the Dow shedding 90.18 to 8816.25 and the S&P losing 3.61 to 1095.55. 

Also hurting stocks was the news that OPEC members and other oil-producing countries have agreed to slash production in an effort to boost slipsliding crude prices. Oil prices leapt $1.82 per barrel to $15.04, sending the Philadelphia Stock Exchange Oil-Service Index geysering 6.8% and the American Stock Exchange Oil & Gas Index up 1.6%. But one index's prize often is another's poison: The Dow Jones Transportation Average plunged 2.2% as airlines were shot down on the prospect of sharply higher fuel costs. 

Just as they suffered on Friday, tech stocks -- especially big tech stocks -- bounced back today. The Nasdaq Composite Index rose 3.34 to 1792.50 and the large-cap Nasdaq 100 gained 9.75 to 1179.18, led by Microsoft (MSFT:Nasdaq), 3Com (COMS:Nasdaq), Oracle (ORCL:Nasdaq) and Cisco (CSCO:Nasdaq). The small-cap Russell 2000 was off 0.29 to 473.96. 

"It's just been rotation," said Roy Blumberg, chief market strategist at Josephthal. "We had triple-witching on Friday, and tech stocks went down and the rest of the market went up. Basically, the scenario still hasn't changed here: It's the end of the quarter and money managers just want to put money to work. They want to put money into the things that have been working for them." 

Blumberg doesn't expect the OPEC machinations to have a deep or lasting effect on the overall market, but he's among the throng on the Street seeing a continued run-up through the quarter's end and then a drop. "I'm still in the camp that says we have a good chance of seeing a 10% correction in the second quarter," he said. "My old pappy taught me that in the long run, stock prices and earnings have to have some reflection of each other. At some point you have to have the E catch up with the P." 

Equity volume remained robust, although down from Friday's huge levels, and breadth was negative. On the New York Stock Exchange, 1,586 decliners led 1,397 advancers on 631.4 million shares. New Big Board highs topped new lows by 245 to 21. On the Nasdaq, 2,452 decliners outpaced 2,027 advancers on 738.6 million shares. New Nasdaq highs beat new lows by 214 to 52. 

The bond market recovered from modest early weakness, spurred by a Federal Reserve coupon pass. In a coupon pass, the Fed permanently injects cash into the banking system by buying bonds. The 30-year Treasury gained 9/32 to 103 14/32, its yield easing to 5.88%. 

Monday's Company Report 

By Heather MooreStaff Reporter 

(Earnings estimates from First Call; new highs and lows on a closing basis unless otherwise specified.) 

Lockheed Martin (LMT:NYSE), which fell 3/8 to 116 5/8, and Northrop Grumman (NOC:NYSE), which picked up 1/2 to 107 1/2, were unfazed by Attorney General Janet Reno's scolding. But they still couldn't come up with a way to stop the feds from filing suit against the companies' proposed $9 billion merger. 

Arguing that the deal would raise prices and reduce quality, the nation's top law official declared: "This merger isn't just about dollars and cents. It's about winning wars and saving lives." Reno for best actress in a financial farce! (And Clinton for best actor in a foreign drama! Did you see that man  (Chart Omitted) 
yell?) 

* * * * * 

In the "no news, we promise" category: Siebert Financial (SIEB:Nasdaq) tumbled 8 1/4, or 18.2%, to 37 7/16. Last Thursday, the company's stock jumped nearly 15% while the CFO insisted there was no explanation. And while Merrill Lynch (MER:NYSE) closed at 82 7/8, down 7/16, the firm's stock hit 87 1/16 around 12:25 p.m. Re-re-re-re-reheated leftovers from the Chase Manhattan (CMB:NYSE) takeover dream? 

Mergers, acquisitions and joint ventures 

Ultra Pac (UPAC:Nasdaq) skyrocketed 8 1/4, or 122%, to 15 after agreeing to be acquired by Ivex Packaging (IXX:NYSE) for $15.50 per share. Ivex added 1/2 to 22 3/8. 

Circus Circus (CIR:NYSE) lost 3, or 12.1%, to 21 3/4 and Hilton (HLT:NYSE) slid 3/4 to 32 7/8 after the companies announced that their merger talks have collapsed. 

Cendant (CD:NYSE) lost 7/8 to 39 1/8 after announcing an agreement to buy American Bankers Insurance Group (ABI:NYSE) for $67 per share, or $3.1 billion, in cash and stock. American Bankers fell 1/8 to 64 7/16. The agreement ends a two-month bidding war between Cendant and American International Group (AIG:NYSE), which skidded 2 1/16 to 127 5/16. In a separate deal, Cendant also agreed to buy Britain's National Parking for $1.3 billion. 

Atlantic Richfield (ARC:NYSE) jumped 1 1/2 to 81 7/8 after Arch Coal (ACI:NYSE), which gained 1/2 to 26 15/16, said it would buy the company's Colorado and Utah coal operations and combine them with Arco's Wyoming operations. The deal is valued at $1.14 billion. Merrill Lynch upgraded Atlantic Richfield to near-term accumulate from neutral and Prudential upped it to buy from hold. 

Earnings reports and previews 

Creative Computers (MALL:Nasdaq) dived 2 11/32, or 22.1%, to 8 3/8 after saying that it expects to report a first-quarter operating loss because of a slowdown in sales, price pressure and losses at retail outlets. The two-analyst consensus estimate called for earnings of 11 cents per share versus the year-ago 8 cents. The company said it plans to cut 150 jobs and close six stores. 

American HomePatient (AHOM:Nasdaq) jumped 1 1/2, or 7.8%, to 20 7/8 despite reporting fourth-quarter earnings of 31 cents per share, above the year-ago 30 cents but below the seven-analyst estimate of 37 cents. 

Banctec (BTC:NYSE) dropped 2, or 7.7%, to 23 15/16 after the company said it expected to report lower-than-anticipated first-quarter earnings because of lower revenues in its system integration business. The company warned of 46 cents per share compared with the four-analyst prediction of 50 cents. 

Samsonite (SAMC:Nasdaq) plunged 2 1/8, or 6.6%, to 30 5/16 after reporting fourth-quarter earnings of 22 cents per share, up from the year-ago 13 cents. The company also announced a first-quarter charge of $2.6 million to restructure its Torhout, Belgium, softside manufacturing operations. 

Maytag (MYG:NYSE) tacked on 7/16 to 48 3/16 after saying its first-quarter sales are expected to rise by as much as 25% from the year-ago levels because of strong demand for new products introduced last year and improved operating margins. Earnings will be "much better" than the five-analyst prediction of 61 cents per share, the company said. 

Offerings and stock actions 

Consulier Engineering (CSLR:Nasdaq) climbed 2 5/16, or 55.2%, to 6 1/2 after announcing a two-for-one stock split for shareholders of record March 31, payable April 15. 

Analyst actions 

Smith International (SII:NYSE) soared 4 1/2, or 8.4%, to 58 1/8 after Prudential upped it to buy from hold. 

DVI (DVI:NYSE) fell 2, or 8%, to 23 1/16 after SalomonSmith Barney downgraded it to neutral from buy. 

Great Lakes Chemical (GLK:NYSE) flew 3 3/16, or 6.4%, to 52 7/8 after Morgan Stanley Dean Witter raised it to strong buy from outperform. Following President and CEO Robert McDonald's resignation, the company also named Mark Bulriss, currently president of an AlliedSignal (ALD:NYSE) division, president effective April 6. AlliedSignal slipped 1/8 to 42 1/4. 

Baan (BAAN:Nasdaq) shed 3, or 6%, to 47 1/16 after Goldman Sachs cut the company to market outperform from its recommended list. 

Security Capital (SCN:NYSE) gained 1/2 to 25 after SalomonSmith Barney upgraded it to outperform from neutral. 

Financial Federal (FIF:NYSE) picked up 1/2 to 25 1/2 after SalomonSmith Barney raised its price target to 29. 

Hartford Life (HLI:NYSE) slipped 1/8 to 48 3/8 after SalomonSmith Barney lowered it to outperform from buy. 

Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF:NYSE) gave up 2 to 45 1/2 after Bear Stearns lowered it to attractive from buy. 

Miscellany 

Investors got busy on yesterday's news that oil prices will probably soar. Schlumberger (SLB:NYSE) gained 4 9/16, or 6.2%, to 78 1/8, and Halliburton (HAL:NYSE) sprang 3 5/8, or 7.5%, to 51 3/4. Mobil (MOB:NYSE) leapt 13/16 and closed at an all-time high of 79 3/8 after Merrill Lynch raised it to near-term accumulate from neutral and Prudential upgraded it to buy from hold. Texaco (TX:NYSE) tacked on 9/16 to 61 7/8 after ABN AMRO raised it to buy from hold. Unocal (UCL:NYSE) added 1/18 to 41 3/8 after Merrill Lynch raised it to near-term accumulate from neutral. British Petroleum (BP:NYSE) climbed 2 3/8 to 92 after Merrill Lynch increased it to near-term accumulate from neutral. Dow component Exxon (XON:NYSE) raised 7/8 to 68. 

Wall Streeters also moved on the expected high costs for airlines. Delta (DAL:NYSE) declined 2 11/16 to 115 3/4, and American Airlines parent AMR (AMR:NYSE) slipped 13/16 to 139. 

TeleSpectrum Worldwide (TLSP:Nasdaq) climbed 1 19/32, or 34%, to 6 5/16 after naming Keith Alessi chairman, president and CEO. 

Integrated Circuit Systems (ICST:Nasdaq) lowered 3 5/16, or 14%, to 20 1/8 after Friday's post-bell announcement that President and CEO Stavro Prodromou resigned. 

Data Systems Network (DSYS:Nasdaq) slid 7/8, or 12.3%, to 6 1/4 after announcing that a special committee looking into previously announced accounting irregularities is nearing the conclusion of its investigation. The company predicts the results will have an impact of $1.5 million to $2 million in 1996. 

Compaq (CPQ:NYSE) sailed 1 11/16, or 7.3%, to 24 15/16 after the European Commission granted regulatory approval of its acquisition of Digital Equipment (DEC:NYSE), which gained 2 1/4 to 50 3/16. 

ProBusiness Services (PRBZ:Nasdaq) leapt 2 7/16, or 9.2%, to 29 3/4 after Coca-Cola (KO:NYSE) asked the company to provide payroll tax services. Coke sank 1 5/8 to 75 7/8. 

Boeing (BA:NYSE) fell 1 13/16 to 51 5/8 after it was reported that Boeing's new bottlenecks are hampering deliveries of more than 50 737s. 

Disney (DIS:NYSE) lost 4 to 103 after a Barron's report suggested that accounting problems are troubling the company. 

Pfizer (PFE:NYSE) jumped another 4 1/8 to 96 1/4 on, uh, excitement about the company's candidate impotence drug Viagra, which was featured Friday on ABC News' "20/20" program. Pharmaceutical competitor Eli Lilly (LLY:NYSE) drooped down 1 3/4 to 63 1/2 with envy. 

Chiron (CHIR:Nasdaq) gained 5/16 to 21 7/16 on news it has named ex-Glaxo Wellcome (GLX ADR) COO Sean Lance its CEO.

urn:contentItem:5WDY-70N1-JB5Y-N28T-00000-00In World First, Facebook to Give Data on Hate Speech suspects to French Courts2019-06-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:55ZLexisNexisIn World First, Facebook to Give Data on Hate Speech suspects to French Courts

Jun 25, 2019( Voice of America: http://www.voanews.com Delivered by Newstex) In a world first, Facebook has agreed to hand over the identification data of French users suspected of hate speech on its platform to judges, France's minister for digital affairs Cedric O said on Tuesday.O, whose father is South Korean, is one of French President Emmanuel Macron's earliest followers, and has been influential in shaping the president's thinking on Big Tech as an advisor at the Elysee palace in the first two years of Macron's presidency.The decision by the world's biggest social media network comes after successive meetings between Zuckerberg and Macron, who wants to take a leading role globally on the regulation of hate speech and the spread of false information online.So far, Facebook has cooperated with French justice on matters related to terrorist attacks and violent acts by transferring the IP addresses and other identification data of suspected individuals to French judges who formally demanded it.Following a meeting between Nick Clegg, Facebook's head of global affairs, and O last week, the social media company has extended this cooperation to hate speech."This is huge news, it means that the judicial process will be able to run normally," O told Reuters in an interview. "It's really very important, they're only doing it for France."O, who said he had been in close contact with Clegg over the last few days on the issue, said Facebook's decision was the result of an ongoing conversation between the internet giant and the French administration.Since his nomination as minister in March, O has made the fight against hate speech online a key priority through regular contacts with Facebook's top executives, including founder Mark Zuckerberg.Facebook declined to comment.Strong signal"It is a strong signal in terms of regulation," said Sonia Cisse, a counsel at law firm Linklaters, adding that it was a world first.

"Hate speech is no longer considered part of freedom of speech, it's now on the same level as terrorism."With Facebook's latest move, France is now a clear frontrunner in the quest to regulate big social media outlets, and other platforms might follow suite, Cisse said.The discussions on how to best regulate tech giants began with a Zuckerberg-Macron meeting last year, followed by a report on tech regulation last month that Facebook's founder considered could be a blueprint for wider EU regulation.Facebook had refrained from handing over identification data of people suspected of hate speech because it was not compelled to do so under U.S.-French legal conventions and because it was worried countries without an independent judiciary could abuse it.France's parliament, where Macron's ruling party has a comfortable majority, is debating legislation that would give the new regulator the power to fine tech companies up to 4% of their global revenue if they don't do enough to remove hateful content from their network.O also signaled his openness to seeing French startups being snapped up by larger U.S. companies, in a spite of recent measures taken by Macron's government to bolster anti-takeover rules to protect the country's strategic companies."My only goal is to spur the creation of a lot of companies," he said. "I have no problem with the fact that some of them are bought by U.S. companies, as long as they don't have critical technology."Too bigThe minister is also reluctant to support the idea of breaking up companies like Facebook or Google, whose size, weight on the Internet and financial firepower have turned them into systemic players just as much as big banks.Facebook has been called a social media monopoly by co-founder Chris Hughes, and calls for a break-up of the group have intensified."We cannot impose very tough obligations on Western companies and dismantle them because they are very big, and not do the same thing with Chinese companies that enter the Western market," he said, referring to groups like Alibaba and Tencent.A graduate of France's top business school, HEC, O combines political experience - he was an aide to Dominique Strauss-Khan, like many of the tight group of "Macron Boys" who propelled him to power - and a stint in the private sector, at engine maker Safran.At the Elysee, he was in charge of advising Macron on the French government's vast portfolio of stakes in French companies, having to deal with hot corporate sagas such as Renault-Nissan, as well as handling relations with Big Tech.
