Corporate Participants

* Fernando Passos

IRB-Brasil Resseguros S.A. - Deputy CEO, CFO, IR Officer & VP

* Lucas Aristides Mello

IRB-Brasil Resseguros S.A. - Strategy & Innovation Director

* Marcelo Hirata

IRB-Brasil Resseguros S.A. - Information Technology & Facilities Director

Conference Call Participants

* Carlos Eduardo Daltozo

Eleven Financial Research - Head of Variable Income

* Eduardo Rosman

Banco BTG Pactual S.A., Research Division - Analyst

* Marco Calvi

ItaÃº Corretora de Valores S.A., Research Division - Research Analyst

* VinÃ­cius Soares

BB-Banco de Investimento S.A., Research Division - Analyst

* Lucy Sousa

AssociaÃ§Ã£o dos Analistas e Profissionais de Investimento do Mercado de Capitais - President of Apimec Nacional

Presentation

LUCY SOUSA, PRESIDENT OF APIMEC NACIONAL, ASSOCIAÃ§Ã£O DOS ANALISTAS E PROFISSIONAIS DE INVESTIMENTO DO MERCADO DE CAPITAIS: Good morning. Could you please take your seats and could you please turn off your cell phones? We're recording this meeting as well. And it will be broadcasted through the Internet. And during the Q&A session, we kindly request you to raise your hands as always and wait for the microphone so you can pose your question so that everyone can see what we're doing.

So it's with great pleasure that Apimec SÃ£o Paulo, represented by myself, I am Lucy Sousa, I'm the Chairman of Apimec SÃ£o Paulo. This is the reinsurance IRB-Brasil company, that is part of the Novo Mercado; and those that are following us through the Internet. And I would also like to introduce here, Mr. Fernando Passos, Deputy CEO, Chief Financial Officer and Investor Relations Officer; Marcelo Hirata, Information Technology and Facilities Director; Lucas Aristides Mello, Strategy and Innovation Director.

And I would like to give the floor to Fernando Passos.

FERNANDO PASSOS: The Brazilian market, well, I believe that we have 37% of market share. The second player has 6% of market share. Now when we compare the business models between IRB and the other reinsurance companies, I believe that this is not -- we have -- our business model is to be a leader in the insurance contracts. And like in the union, you have a player that is a leader that prices the risk, that discusses the clauses or the conditions that are created with the insurance company is the one that sees with the insurance the great risk and seeing the pricing and seeing probabilities of [luck], and we regulate the major claims.

So this is the figure of the leader of the union. And generally, within the union, you have a group of followers that are capital providers and that follow the decisions of a leader. When there is a claim, you don't have 15 reinsurance companies, each one doing their loss adjustments, their claim -- well, the leader does this and the main players follow the leader. The IRB has a predominant position in terms of reinsurance contracts in Brazil.

Now the business model of our competitors is geared towards -- they're like followers of this position. So when we see the specific Brazilian market and when we see the South American market specifically, none of them have customized solutions for the digital business world or the new businesses that are emerging in the world, like IRB has.

I believe that the case study that Lucas showed you, that a Big Tech wants to create an insurance company. This is a global company that wants to create an insurance company. Instead of going after a big insurance company, they wanted to talk to a local reinsurance company because we have partnerships in other places, by and large. This is our view.

CARLOS EDUARDO DALTOZO, HEAD OF VARIABLE INCOME, ELEVEN FINANCIAL RESEARCH: Carlos Daltozo from Financial Company. You showed us a scenario of the rupture of the insurance market, and you're a very important vehicle for new players, Big Tech, logistics companies and other sectors of the market. My question is, today, where does regulation clash into regulation because you're engaged in these new technologies?

FERNANDO PASSOS: Daltozo, just a comment. We do not see a scenario of rupture. We see a scenario of deep transformation, where new players are going to emerge in the digital world. But at the same time, we will see an evolution of the traditional players that are going towards this direction. And as IRB has prepared itself to service this new business model, this has become an important asset for us because we're providing additional services to our customers that would be the insurance companies and their digital transformation process.

Now regarding regulation, and maybe Lucas can add something, we have already -- we believe that the Brazilian regulators and some regulators in South America, like in the case of Colombia, in the case of Peru, and the regulators are holding public hearings and they're changing the regulation to allow to develop these new business that are evolving -- that are emerging in the digital world.

Lucas, would you like to say something?

LUCAS ARISTIDES MELLO: And something else, just to have a clear vision, and going back to the main comments in the presentation, I believe that the innovation will take place in the market. The regulator is never innovative and they shouldn't be because they should always regulate. And when innovation is developed within the company, the regulator has to follow this methodology.

As we can see in SUSEP, we have new updates, new announcements of sandboxes. When you -- because we want to improve the life of the startups and the companies that want to embark in the new scenario, the message that we want to convey to the market, don't worry a lot about regulation. Yes, we have to execute and we have to broaden the market, and yes, we would be able to capture the results of all of this.

And we have seen a very important evolution from SUSEP regarding regulation. So when we compare what SUSEP is doing comparison to American and European regulators, because they're ahead of us, I believe that SUSEP is not lagging behind when you compare them to the regulators of these developed countries. So I believe that SUSEP now is being very positive, and they are supporting this type of innovation that, of course, will improve the life of our consumers.

FERNANDO PASSOS: And Lucas talks a lot to them, and we believe that SUSEP is doing an excellent job regarding the regulation of this new world that is emerging.

CARLOS EDUARDO DALTOZO: Just a second question, if you could answer, of course. But the partnership with Big Tech, is it Latin America or Brazil?

LUCAS ARISTIDES MELLO: It starts with Brazil, and we can extend it throughout South America, not Latin America. We recently held a debate together with the directors of SUSEP, and we talked about technology, and we believe that their position is very interesting. Especially regarding blockchain, SUSEP sees this very positively. SUSEP's vision of seeing blockchain and understanding that this could be much better, so -- and this will help them to inspect, to regulate and to carry out auditing. They believe that with good data, they can work better and this is the future, and this is what they should follow. I believe that this is a broad debate that they're having within the SUSEP environment.

EDUARDO ROSMAN, ANALYST, BANCO BTG PACTUAL S.A., RESEARCH DIVISION: Eduardo Rosman, BTG Pactual Bank. Two questions here. Number one, I would like to know if you can elaborate about your partnership with C6. So what kind of services are you offering? Because I understand that in a certain way, you are also going to the insurance market. So these are 2 sides.

And the second question would be in the release of your earnings result of the third quarter you clarified that you were able to improve significantly the retrocession contract. This expense that is an important expense, we believe that it will drop next year. Could you please tell us why this happened? How these negotiations took place? Up to what extent can you go? And perhaps, this is the main driver that will allow you to gain margin in the upcoming years.

FERNANDO PASSOS: Thank you very much, Rosman. So we will talk about both subjects and Lucas and Hirata, you can add anything. C6 is a digital bank. It was just launched. It became operational very recently. And when we see -- when we try -- of course, IRB was only positioned in the insurance market and they came to talk to us so that we, together, could develop the insurance operation that would be matched with bancassurance of a digital bank that was emerging. So we worked together on this project.

In the beginning, they decided not to have an insurance company. They created something that you call an MGA, that would be the bank together with IRB, outlined the process and insurance -- the customers' insurance experience. C6 is responsible for all the front end, all the interaction, all the development of the tool that interacts with the customer. IRB is responsible for everything regarding development and everything regarding pricing, claim regulation.

And together, we chose an insurance company that is Fairfax insurance company. Fairfax also contributed with their know-how. They have been a long-term partner. And the 3 companies outlined the model, the interaction with the customer is done by C6. So the pricing method is done by the IRB and also the business rules regarding claim regulations. So the insurer and policies that are sold through the C6 platform, they have (inaudible) that we announced.

Now these type of businesses, they don't make sense if they are not backed by a long-term insurance contract. So we cannot support a partner in best times, contribute with know-how for them to develop their insurance business and to have a 1-year reinsurance contract. So what we have is a proportional reinsurance contract of 10 years that can be renewed for 10 more years. And IRB and the other partners will be able to capture the results in the long term. So in a nutshell, the transaction that was announced between the partnership C6, Fairfax and IRB follows this structure.

Now speaking specifically about the retrocession contract, it's interesting because this was object of our first Apimec meeting, and here we could detail how these contracts worked. The IRB, during the last 3 years, has dropped its cost of retrocession. Unfortunately, during this year renewals -- well, this year, we were able to be very successful in this process, and we will be able to drop our cost of retrocession as we announced in our earnings result and this was dropped. And this reduction -- this was because of our technological development. And now we can give data to our retrocession contracts and now they can better price our risk. Now this technological evolution has helped us to improve the cost of retrocession.

Another point that has helped us is as the IRB has been recognized by the global reinsurance market in B3, B3i has 12 shareholders that are founding shareholders. So the IRB -- as IRB is part of this group, it shows you how the community is respecting IRB. And this translates in different players that are interested in working with us that in the past weren't interested in working with us. And now I believe that there is a more competitive process.

Now this year was different from last year and it was also different from 2014. I believe that in the year 2014, we were running after the retrocession contracts. Now this year, I believe we had a higher volume of offers and our underwriting volume was 3x more. So I believe that the competition lowered the price. So even the track record of the IRB, when we compare it to our claims, was also very important when we prove that the level of claims that we have today is stable. And I believe that the retrocessionaires feel more at ease to working with us. In the summary, it's this.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Can you hear me? Just a follow-up on the retrocession issue. What can you tell us about the foreign exchange risk? We have the dollar going up and in the older contracts we had a forward-sold contracts. So were those contracts renewed or not?

FERNANDO PASSOS: For this year's contract, as we did back in 2018 and '19, once again, we managed to negotiate our retrocession contracts in terms of having a cap for the U.S. dollar. Unlike what happened in 2019 where the cap was set at around 3.3, this year, we established a cap at 3.52. So there is a cap for 2020 but at a slightly higher level than we had for this year 2019, from 3.30 to 3.52.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: My name is [Manuel] and my first question -- you mentioned growth drivers for IRB, retrocession and others. My question is, what are the main drivers for the company, for the company's future growth in terms of revenue, performance? And how does that play out going forward?

FERNANDO PASSOS: One of the growth drivers that we would like to cite that -- well, it's all that we have showed this morning, these new businesses emerging in the digital arena which will have a great impact, and Lucas said it very well, that has the potential to boost the company's growth in the mid-term, I'm talking about 5 years' horizon.

When we look at the Brazil's reality in terms of growth perspective for the company, for the market of reinsurance for 2020, what draws our attention is agribusiness-related insurance and reinsurance businesses. The Brazilian government has increased its subsidies for the purchase of farmers. It moved from BRL 400 million to BRL 1 billion as they pushed for 2020.

Recently, for those of you who want to know, the Ministry of Agriculture has posted on its website, projections that they believe represent the growth potential for agriculture-related insurance businesses. So I'm talking about an official information source and is available to anyone who wishes to consult.

Another growth driver in Brazil is the oil and gas industry. So as the last auctions have shown -- the last auctions promoted by the ANP, our oil fields have shown that the oil and gas industry has been growing faster than the GDP growth. So it has been an important growth leverage for 2019 and will continue to be so next year, an important growth leverage, the oil and gas industry.

Another element that was also important for our growth this year and that we see as a sustainable driver for next year as well has to do with the pricing of real estate assets, broadly speaking. The coverage limits for properties is pegged to the value of the properties, especially commercial properties. And with everything that has been happening with the interest rates, of course, pricing for real estate is going up. And with that, coverages are expanded. And with that, the premiums also grow.

And also, look, it's something that the company also was looking into in terms of customer management, that this is more a belief that we have for 2020, the civil construction industry, the housing industry. We see new launches, new housing starts and that's a driver under the engineering risks pillar, which was sort of latent for the last 4, 5 years because we had fewer housing starts, fewer launches. If that recovery does materialize, that, of course, will boost that line of business as well. So those would be the main drivers that we see materializing for next year in terms of Brazil.

When we look at the company's growth in South America, we believe that the company's market share is so limited in South America, ex Brazil, that our growth depends on IRB itself. In other words, the services that we are able to provide to our customers rather than on a market growth as a whole. Not in Brazil, of course, because we hold 37% of the market, so our growth has to do with market growth. But when we look at South America, our growth is more dependent on IRB positioning itself as a closer player, providing support, also in terms of digital transformation, as it was said, and then we can increase our share.

LUCY SOUSA: Anybody else? Any other question? Fernando?

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Can I ask a question? You said it very well when you talked about data, and we see that you are concerned about monitoring climate risks. Is that a work that is done internally? Or are you proactively looking or searching support from universities or other institutions? You mentioned the agricultural side, even for oil and gas, we just witnessed this disaster in our northeastern shore, of course that involves insurance as well. So I'd like to hear that from you, climate issues.

FERNANDO PASSOS: Perhaps Hirata could talk about the systems and I'll talk about the partnerships we have. We have partnerships with several institutions that help us make that kind of projection. Hirata might talk about the system, but I can always say that we have a very important partnership with Embrapa as they are an important provider in terms of climate data and also for the agricultural areas.

Embrapa is a very strong partner, has been with us for a long time since we were a state-owned company. And we have deep respect for Embrapa, and they provide big support for agriculture in Brazil. The IRB has a very strong partnership with them. And we also have other partnerships with private entities that provide services concerning information, not only in Brazil but in South America as a whole.

LUCAS ARISTIDES MELLO: Thank you, Fernando. And additionally, the application allows us to have or to share that monitoring, that's not only within IRB. All those partners that were mentioned by Fernando, they have access to the information, have access to the data and they might be able to generate notifications and alerts so that preventive action might be taken should a disaster happen or even to monitor proposals in the agribusiness realm or other areas.

If I may, as Hirata mentioned RMS, the IRB has developed a unique model to monitor climate in agriculture in Brazil. It will be the first model of climate modeling in Brazil developed by IRB, developed by or in conjunction with the multinational company, the RMS, and we'll make that available for the market to help boost the insurance market in the agricultural area along with Embrapa as it was mentioned. So with the statistical data, including soil profile, pasture quality, all of that will allow us to develop this model. And this model was about to be launched right, Hirata?

VINÃ­CIUS SOARES, ANALYST, BB-BANCO DE INVESTIMENTO S.A., RESEARCH DIVISION: Mr. Soares from Banco do Brasil. You talk about scalability and return or returns in the mid-term, 5 years, as you mentioned. Can we expect IRB accepting lower margins and contracts in order to gain scale or gain share or even accepting or buying higher risks than it does today? Can we envision that going forward?

FERNANDO PASSOS: VinÃ­cius, what we see in business plans, specifically in that case, that is shown by Lucas, even the case study of the logistics company and what we see in business plans for healthtechs, construtechs, other companies which are getting ready to launch their insurance business, we're talking about even larger margins that we see in the reinsurance market today.

I'll give you an example. Going back to the C6 Bank case, to make it more material. With the C6 Bank, we'll have a shareholder in their insurance business, bancassurance. When we look at the insurance business for traditional banks, it's usually a business of a higher profitability, higher than our reinsurance business and which is withheld under the insurance companies controlled by banks.

So as we see it, and the C6 case is a concrete case and the business plans of insurance companies being developed by tech companies, that shows us that the IRB will be able to access a business niche of retail business which, today, is barely touched on the service. And it is a business that provides higher margins than the corporate risks arm. So it's the opposite, actually, as we understand it. Even though for the final customer, they'll have better pricing because those business were not accessed by the reinsurance market. The trend is that we'll see higher margins for the company, not lower.

LUCY SOUSA: Unfortunately, our time is up, and nobody else wanted to ask question. So on behalf of Apimec SÃ£o Paulo, I'd like to thank you all for this very productive meeting, very interesting topics were discussed. And thank you all for participating, both physically and those with us remotely via the Internet. Once again, Apimec is celebrating its 50th anniversary. And I give the floor over to Fernando for his final remarks and closing of the session.

FERNANDO PASSOS: All right. Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for participating. Thank you for your time. A big thank you to all analysts for your time, your time dedicated to the company, the patience you have shown towards us and trying -- in terms of learning about a relatively new business in Brazil.

Thank you to all our colleagues, all our investors who have shown a lot of confidence in the company. Thank you. Have a nice day, everyone.

EDITOR: Statements in English on this transcript were spoken by an interpreter present on the live call. The interpreter was provided by the Company sponsoring this Event.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5DC7-71X1-DY60-K3JK-00000-00Ireland closes tax loophole for tech giants2014-10-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:55ZLexisNexisCOMPANY NEWSIreland closes tax loophole for tech giantsAlanna Petroff

For years, some of the world's biggest companies have set up shop in Ireland to dodge taxes. Now, Ireland is taking a key tax break away.

The move mostly affects big tech and drug companies, including Google.

Companies currently using a special kind of tax loophole must stop by the end of 2020, and new companies will be barred from using this loophole starting in 2015.

Experts say the change is not particularly aggressive and is designed to placate the international community, which perceives Ireland to be using unfair tactics to attract outside investment from big companies.

"In many respects, I think this change of law is to improve public relations and inter-government relations with the United States," said Ryan Dudley, a partner specializing in international taxes at Friedman LLP in New York.

Dudley predicts the change won't ultimately mean any more tax revenue for the U.S., or even Ireland.

"The companies will restructure," he said.

Indeed, Ireland said it is considering new tax breaks. Details of this offer are still in the works.

Ireland's move Tuesday is part of a broader effort to clamp down on tax avoidance by multinationals.

Google and Apple, for instance, are among the companies that have come under fire for shifting profit between international subsidiaries to take advantage of low tax rates in foreign countries.

The European Union's top regulator is currently investigating Apple's tax affairs in Ireland, claiming the company may have benefited from special treatment through a deal with Irish authorities.

Ireland's corporate tax rate -- at 12.5% -- is much lower than those offered in most other developed nations. But Apple has paid as little as 2% on profit attributed to its subsidiaries in Ireland.

Google responded to the Irish tax tweak by saying it would comply with the rules.

"As we've always said, it's for governments to decide the law and for companies to comply with it. We're deeply committed to Ireland and will work to implement these changes as they become law," the company said in a statement.

Apple maintained that it does not receive special treatment from Irish authorities, and would not comment directly on the latest Irish tax changes.

Updated at 2:15 pm ET with new lead, edits throughout.

By Alanna PetroffLONDON (CNNMoney)

LONDON (CNNMoney) -- For years, some of the world's biggest companies have set up shop in Ireland to dodge taxes. Now, Ireland is taking a key tax break away.

The move mostly affects big tech and drug companies, including Google.

"The companies will restructure," he said.

Indeed, Ireland said it is considering new tax breaks. Details of this offer are still in the works.

Ireland's move Tuesday is part of a broader effort to clamp down on tax avoidance by multinationals.

Google and Apple, for instance, are among the companies that have come under fire for shifting profit between international subsidiaries to take advantage of low tax rates in foreign countries.

Ireland's corporate tax rate -- at 12.5% -- is much lower than those offered in most other developed nations. But Apple has paid as little as 2% on profit attributed to its subsidiaries in Ireland.

Google responded to the Irish tax tweak by saying it would comply with the rules.

"As we've always said, it's for governments to decide the law and for companies to comply with it. We're deeply committed to Ireland and will work to implement these changes as they become law," the company said in a statement.

Apple maintained that it does not receive special treatment from Irish authorities, and would not comment directly on the latest Irish tax changes.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60NW-F1X1-JCF5-V0N4-00000-00Ireland: Healthcare Transformation The Human Factor2020-08-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:55ZLexisNexisIreland: Healthcare Transformation The Human Factor

The headlines across the globe tell a story of transformation, reform and renewal within the healthcare sector.

We are constantly being advised that traditional healthcare is being reimagined.

Many of the patients currently attending hospitals, will, we are told, never need to attend in the future, as AI powered predictive care will prevent many of the health issues that normally fill our hospitals.

Digital records on the Social Determinants of Health (SDOH) such as inherited medical conditions, what we eat, where we work and whether we have access to stable and clean living conditions will allow us anticipate whether we are risk and take preventative measures at a very early stage and thereby avoid being hospitalised.

As hospitals are given the "digital equivalent of brains and a nervous system"

Michael Rodgers futurist health management.org Volume 20 issue 1 2020

 such as smart sensors, artificial intelligence, robotics and automation, technology will now facilitate immediate patient scanning, assessment and treatment delivery, which will transition seamlessly from the "Hospo-Tech" to the home.

Hospital and homecare will be connected to a single digital infrastructure tracking vulnerable patients earlier and deploying healthcare professionals and patients to where they can best serve and be served across multiple locations.

"The glue that binds this network together is no longer location..... it is the experiences of the people it serves."

World Economic Forum 7 January 2020, Carla Kriwetceo Connected Care and Health Informatics.

This view that it is the people and not just the technology that are key to unlocking the heralded transformation in healthcare delivery is worth exploring further. It is important that we interrogate and understand the real drivers of transformation so that we can be certain that the changes we are beginning to see are fully enabled to deliver the patient empowered, patient centric, community wide care delivery system we so desperately need.

While this headline worthy vision of transformation in healthcare may seem whimsical and wishful thinking to many, in fact, the vision for this type of connected care system has been considered and promoted for the last decade.

In Ireland, Sláintecare (the 10-year program to transform our health system) was first considered in 2016 when the future of healthcare committee was established by the Dáil (after much debate on the need for reform). The objective of Sláintecare is to keep people well at home for as long as possible and provide timely access to hospital services when necessary.

The technology has also been available for some time. The MedTech sector in Ireland generates circa 12 bn in exports annually and employs 32,000 people in Ireland. The global telemedicine market size was estimated at USD $41.4 bn in 2019.

Arguably, the transformation hitting the headlines now is not as a result of any new vison or new technology alone, but more interestingly is a result of a transformative shift in mindset.

Historically, there has been a real reluctance to adopt new technologies in healthcare. The contrast to the rates of adoption in communications or retail is stark. Patients have been slow to opt for innovation over traditional person-to-person care. Doctors worry about technology failures caused by outages or simple human input error. Going digital creates extra work, familiarizing oneself with new technology in an overstretched care environment with systems that work "well enough". Within the existing infrastructure, investment in digital is rarely a priority. Hospital administrators are reluctant to spend tight budgets on cutting edge technology, if neither patient nor physician are likely to change their behavior and adopt it.

The Corona Virus pandemic has been a gamechanger, compelling both patient and physician to use technology advances to facilitate their treatment. It is this culture shift that will accelerate the role of technology in health care. Increased adoption will drive further investment and encourage innovation.

Year over year, Q2 2020 saw a surge of over 22% in VC investment in life sciences with a quarterly high of USD $7.8bn.

In the UK, Dr. Doctor's video consultation portal solution and Intouch's integrated virtual clinics management platform, which were scheduled for release in late 2020, accelerated their development and launched earlier this year to alleviate pressure on NHS hospitals as they struggled to cope with managing and treating patients during the pandemic. By connecting the portal to the platform, patients can now manage their appointments, launch video consultations, complete digital assessment forms and check in for their in-person appointment all from home. The potential for this technology is only just being explored, prompting the CEO of Guys and St. Thomas, NHS Trust to encourage colleagues to "come and see the system live and consider what it can do in your practice".

Medtechnews.com 4 June 2020

While this digital shift is to be encouraged for the efficiencies and personalised care it enables, if, as we suggest, it is being driven by people as much as technology, then it is vital that it is managed and regulated in a way which builds patient and physician trust while avoiding unnecessary dampeners on innovation.

Paul Reid Director General of the HSE commented in a Business Post article Sunday August 9 2020 that Covid 19 has fast tracked reforms in the Irish health system that may have taken years to happen otherwise.

Paul Reid is eager, he said, to run with this momentum and recognise the new world we are living in, focusing on actions, targeted to give a bigger impact: "Anything that involved tele-health and community services needs to be accelerated" along with "the development of community-based healthcare".

Technology is at the core of these objectives. However, the development and roll out of these technologies is not straightforward. There are many twists and turns ahead before we successfully reimagine healthcare delivery.

The real catalysts may be the shift in mindset, the culture change, the desire and state of readiness to be part of a system exploring new ways of doing more with less in a patient centric way. That perhaps is the real transformation coming from the pandemic and not the technology itself.

If this is indeed the case (and there is evidence to suggest it is), then Paul Reid should focus first on the people at the centre of this "new world"; the patient, the physician, the innovator. He should ask them what it will take to ensure they feel secure enough to swop face-to-face for screen-to-screen consultation and treatment; what will enable them to trust the AI delivered analytics; and what will incentivise them to innovate for a better healthcare system.

A 2019 digital risk report and white paper RSA Digital Risk in Healthcare Today 2019 identified the major risks emerging from digital transformation in the healthcare sector.

These risks include:

Cyber-attack

In the US in 2019 healthcare was one of the top two industries most targeted by cyber threats

Statista - 5 August 2019.

As wearables, apps, sensors, robotics, monitors and implants make up the internet of medical things and as they are deployed to a myriad of users across many different platforms, they are very vulnerable to cyber-attack. Cyber security threats remain the biggest drawback to increased digitalisation in healthcare. Investment in robust data security systems and blockchain technologies will be as important a driver of digital health as wearable devices and mobile monitors.

Data Privacy

In the two years between 2016 and 2018, healthcare data grew 878% and it was expected (pre pandemic) that by the end of this year at least 25% of all healthcare data will be collected by the patient themselves. While GDPR sets the ground rules for regulating data privacy and in particular special category data such as healthcare data, risk management practices must keep pace with digital transformation efforts. As healthcare workers provide care from multiple locations, they require secure and rapid access to information by mobile and web based applications and in so doing risk exposing healthcare organisations to improper use and access.

AI and Data Analytics

Quality machine learning requires quality data. Biased data can lead to biased models and algorithms that function differently in different populations. Given the breadth of machine learning uses across healthcare, the breadth of techniques in use and the breadth of data and human involvement, the requirement for any given machine-learning algorithm depends heavily on the context. Opacity in machine learning may impair our ability to assess medical devices safety and effectiveness. Where machine learning constantly retrains using incremental learning from streaming data, we need to be able to assess the safety and effectiveness of these models in real time.

While AI is not explicitly mentioned in the GDPR, many of its provisions are relevant to the use of AI. However, there are tensions emerging between traditional data protection principles such as purpose limitation and data minimization and the full deployment of the powers of AI. In addition, a number of AI related data protection issues are not addressed in the GDPR. Controllers and processors are calling for additional guidance. The Scientific Foresight Unit (European Parliament June 2020) has called for a broad social, political and legal debate on what standards should apply to processing of personal data using AI. The debate, it is felt, should also address what applications should be barred and which may be admitted under specific circumstances and controls.

Conclusion

If building momentum around the acceleration of digital health technologies is the goal the government, the HSE and the private sector must focus on the management, mitigation and regulation of risk areas so as to build trust across the human network as much as the enablement of the technology itself.

If the transformation in healthcare has in fact been accelerated not just by technology but by people and their willingness to adapt and adopt, the continuation of this transformation toward a future vision of "being consumer centric, efficient and based on high quality data and accessible technology" depends on our ability to build and maintain trust in the new healthcare infrastructure. Big Tech has shown us too many examples of what can happen when trust is an afterthought, a nice to have when everything else is in place, for us to let it happen in healthcare when it is truly a matter of life or death.

The content of this article is intended to provide a general guide to the subject matter. Specialist advice should be sought about your specific circumstances.


Ms Gillian Keating
Ronan Daly Jermyn

Mahon Point
Cork

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y8V-Y4B1-JCF5-V2CP-00000-00Ireland: Highlights Of The Data Protection Commission's Annual Report For 20192020-02-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:55ZLexisNexisIreland: Highlights Of The Data Protection Commission's Annual Report For 2019Brian Johnston

On 20 February 2020, Ireland's data protection supervisory authority, the Data Protection Commission (DPC), published its annual report for 2019 (Report). The Report is the second report under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and is the first report based on a full calendar year under the GDPR.

2019 statistics

The Report reveals 2019 has been an exceptionally busy year for the DPC. It contains a number of interesting statistics, in particular:

Complaints: 7,215 complaints received; 75% increase from 2018; 29% in access rights category; 5,496 complaints concluded, and 457 cross-border processing complaints received through the One-Stop Shop mechanismBreaches: 6,069 valid data breach notifications received; 71% increase from 2018 and 83% related to unauthorised disclosuresInquiries: 70 inquiries as of 31 December 2019; 21 cross-border inquiries, and 49 domestic inquiriesDirect marketing: 165 new complaints investigated; 77 related to email marketing; 81 related to SMS marketing; seven related to telephone marketing, and prosecutions concluded against four entitiesGeneral consultation queries: 1,420 queries received; 44% from the private/financial sector, and 33% from the public sectorData Protection Officers: 712 new Data Protection Officer notifications, bringing the total number to 1,596 at year endContacts: 22,300 emails; 22,200 telephone call, and almost 4,000 items of post.Staff: increase from 110 at the end of 2018 to 140 at the end of 2019Communications and guidance: 33 guidance documents, 18 blogs, 8 podcasts, 20,000 social media followersBinding Corporate Rules: lead reviewer in 19 Binding Corporate Rules applications

Summary of key sections

Complaints

There has been a significant increase in the number of complaints received. As in previous years, access requests complaints were identified as the highest complaint-type received by the DPC between in 2019 - 2,064 complaints. A high proportion of these related to the failure of organisations to respond to an access request, or failure to release all the appropriate data on foot of an access request.

The DPC is the lead supervisory authority for a broad range of multinationals and the Report sets out that 457 cross-border complaints were transferred to the DPC by other data protection supervisory authorities in 2019.

Breaches

Some of the trends and issues related to breaches identified in the Report include:

Late notificationsDifficulty in assessing risk ratingsFailure to communicate the breach to individualsRepeat breach notificationsInadequate reporting

There has been an increase in the number of repeat breaches of a similar nature by a large number of companies, particularly in the financial sector, where the majority of breaches appear to be related to unauthorised disclosures.

Inquiries

Investigations into big tech companies continued to progress in 2019 with the first two inquiries moving from the investigative stage to the decision-making phase. The Report states that it is going to take time to implement the new legal frameworks under the GDPR but assures readers that intensive work is underway. The Report anticipates that 2020 will involve the reconciliation of many such complex legal issues which will flow from the conclusion of its first waves of statutory inquiries and the crystallisation in practical terms of many theoretical legal and procedural issues which have been raised during those first novel inquiries.

Cookies

In 2019, the DPC examined the use of cookies and similar technologies on a selection of websites across a range of sectors, including media and publishing, the retail sector, restaurants and food ordering services, insurance, sport and leisure and the public sector. The Report states that the quality of information provided to users in relation to cookies varied widely and confirms that during 2020, the DPC will produce updated guidance on cookies and other technologies. The Report notes that the DPC will place a strong focus on compliance in this area.

Children

The Report informs us that the DPC is now finalising its guidance document on children's data protection rights and the processing of children's data having carried out an extensive consultation on the processing of children's personal data. In tandem with the guidance, the DPC will publish a separate child-friendly guide which will explain to children their rights under data protection law and the risks that may arise when they disclose their personal data online.

Regulatory Strategy 2020-2025

Among the DPC's key projects in the Report is its Regulatory Strategy 2020-2025. The DPC commenced consultations last year to understand people's views on data protection rights, the role of the DPC, how compliance with data protection law should be encouraged, facilitated, and maximised, and how non-compliance should be regulated. The draft Regulatory Strategy is being developed and will be subject to a further open public consultation during 2020.

Case studies and litigation

The Report contains various case studies and details of litigation the DPC is involved in. The case studies cover matters including data subject rights data and data breaches. The Report also contains summaries of the data protection elements of significant judgments delivered by the European Court of Justice (CJEU) during 2019, the litigation concerning standard contractual clauses in the Irish courts and the CJEU and the DPC's investigation in relation to the public services card.

The content of this article is intended to provide a general guide to the subject matter. Specialist advice should be sought about your specific circumstances.


Mr Brian Johnston
Mason Hayes ; Curran
South Bank House,
Barrow Street,
Dublin
IRELAND
Tel: 1614 5000
Fax: 1614 5001
E-mail: events@mhc.ie
URL: www.mhc.ie

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:606J-7J41-DYWP-R0H4-00000-00Ireland, Luxembourg need more muscle to police tech giants, EU report says2020-06-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:55ZLexisNexisBUSINESSIreland, Luxembourg need more muscle to police tech giants, EU report says

BRUSSELS: Ireland and Luxembourg, European headquarters to Google, Facebook, Twitter and Amazon, need a substantial boost in resources to deal with data breaches by U.S. tech giants, a European Union report said. The report by the European Commission, seen by Reuters, sought to assess the effectiveness of the EU's landmark data privacy rules known as the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) adopted in 2018. GDPR requires companies to seek people's consent before using their personal data or face steep fines. European Vice President for Values and Transparency Vera Jourova has previously lauded the rules as a compass to guide the EU into the digital age.

The report said that data protection agencies across the 27-country bloc had increased staff by 42per cent increase and budgets by 49per cent between 2016-2019, but the Irish and Luxembourg governments needed to do more. "Given that the largest big tech multinationals are established in Ireland and Luxembourg, the data protection authorities of these countries act as lead authorities in many important cross-border cases and may need larger resources than their population would otherwise suggest," the report said. The Irish watchdog has opened cases into Facebook, Facebook-owned Instagram and WhatsApp as well as Twitter, Apple, Verizon Media, Microsoft-owned LinkedIn and U.S. digital advertiser Quantcast. The report urged national watchdogs to launch joint investigations that would lead to more harmonised rules and approaches. It said some of the challenges were reconciling data privacy rights with the right to freedom of expression, and how to apply the rules to technologies such as artificial intelligence, facial recognition, blockchain and the internet of things. Enforcement continues to be the weak link, said Eva Simon at the Civil Liberties Union for Europe. "There are still far too many governments, organisations and businesses flouting the rules," she said. (Reporting by Foo Yun Chee. Editing by Jane Merriman) - Reuters

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5G78-V4X1-DXCW-D43J-00000-00Ireland: Minister Harris speaking at FIBI international banking conference2015-06-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:55ZLexisNexisIreland: Minister Harris speaking at FIBI international banking conferenceDublin

Department of Finance has issued the following news release:

I am pleased to be asked to provide the opening address at the FIBI International Banking Conference 2015 entitled Strategically Positioning IFS.

[I thank Jonathan (Lowey) for his kind introduction]

Before I comment on the international financial services strategy - IFS 2020 I would like to make some brief points on the economy.

After a sharp contraction in output that accompanied the global crisis of 2008 to 2010, Ireland’s economy has experienced a remarkable turnaround. The public finances have been repaired, economic activity and employment are growing, and financial stability has been restored.

Ireland was the fastest-growing economy in the EU last year, and the European Commission forecasts the same again this year. GDP in Ireland grew by 4.8 per cent in 2014. This is the strongest year of annual GDP growth since 2007.

Economic growth is now broadly balanced. Exports are contributing to growth due to competitiveness gains and the domestic economy is now contributing to growth once again.

The economic recovery to date is, in large part, due to the considerable improvement in competitiveness that has taken place in recent years.

Prices and labour costs have grown less in Ireland than in our trading partners. Combined with the recent depreciation of the euro, this has seen Ireland’s competitiveness – as measured by the real effective exchange rate - recover most of the deterioration recorded during the boom years.

This recovery in national competitiveness has facilitated a reallocation of resources towards the tradable sectors of the economy. Exports are now at an all-time high. Ireland has been particularly successful in expanding its share of the world’s services market in recent years and services now account for approximately half of total exports from Ireland.

While the indicators are heading in the right direction we cannot afford to be complacent.

The theme of today’s event only serves to remind that it is important to retain real gains in competiveness not just for the sake of the development of the financial services sector but also to ensure the continued development of the wider economy.

IFS 2020 Strategy

Given the theme of the conference, I will initially address some points in respect of the IFS 2020 Strategy.

It is clear that Ireland has been a success in attracting financial services investment and in recent times growing our own companies who can compete on the world stage.

The sector now employs 35,000 people with a third of those outside Dublin. The importance of the sector in providing sustainable employment across all the State is well recognised.

The Government recognises its importance and engages with a view to ensuring that we retain existing business and employment and grow future employment.

Despite its success financial services in Ireland finds itself at an important juncture.

It is an increasingly a competitive sector and there is global competition for financial services investment.

We are faced with a more competitive period for financial services investment than ever.

However, it seems to me that there are many criteria on which financial services companies base the location of their activity. These can be issues such as

taxation
availability of physical and technological infrastructure
availability of skilled staff
level and scale of financial technological innovation
regulatory environment/government and political stability
access to customers
access to suppliers
costs
culture and quality of life
size of specific markets (e.g. China)

The importance of these will vary according to the sector and financial service activity.

It is important for us to be as competitive as possible in as many of these factors as we can to develop the financial services sector.

However, we also need to understand the markets in which we want to be active – where they add additional business activity, revenue and employment and align our efforts to being competitive in those markets – whether they are in terms of either inward investments or exports.

The IFS 2020 strategy is our statement that we intend to remain competitive for financial services investment.

It is also a statement of intent in terms of the sectors we are seeking to support and develop.

The IFS 2020 strategy seeks to ensure that we protect the progress that has been made but to also to develop further as we recognise that we cannot stand still.

This strategy allows us to make choices in terms of the financial services sectors we can support and nurture.

In terms of vision for the Strategy we want to be recognised as a global location of choice for specialised international financial services, building on our strengths in talent, technology, innovation and excellent client service while focusing on capturing on new opportunities in a changing market and embracing the highest forms of governance.

The strategy places an emphasis on aligning and co-ordinating the marketing and branding of the IFS sector.

There will be greater use of the embassy and consulate network in sharpening our regional focus as well as targeted trade missions. Conferences such as this one and the IFS conference planned for early 2016 demonstrate our intention to support the sector.

Further targeted engagement internationally can have the benefit of attracting investment to Ireland and selling the offering we have in Ireland as a location for financial services.

One of the important proposals in IFS 2020 is engaging with the capital markets union process. Securing more funding for the real economy is an important objective of this ambitious initiative (Capital Markets Union), which will run from 2015 to 2019. CMU, through a wide ranging series of initiatives, aims to make EU capital markets more integrated, liquid and competitive.

Its ultimate purpose is to increase resilience of the financial system and provide greater opportunities for SMEs and longer term infrastructure projects. From an Irish perspective CMU could serve to significantly increase issuer and investor access to more liquid European markets and, in so doing, enable our companies to expand and create employment.

The broad aim of the process is to

Increase funding for business
Create more opportunities for investors
Encourage cross border investment

I doubt there is anyone in the room who would disagree with the aim of the CMU.

I was at a discussion of CMU last week in Brussels.

I am very impressed at the vigour of the Commission and Commissioner (Lord) Hill in bringing the CMU process forward.

I commend Commissioner (Lord) Hill on his work.

It is heartening to hear that 9 per cent of the total submissions to the consultation process initiated by the European Commission came from Ireland which shows the level of interest and involvement from the financial sector in this country.

The approach being adopted by the Commission is to combine long term ambitions with short term early actions.

This is I think is a useful approach and allows for “quick wins” to be achieved.

We want to be in a position to be able to benefit from any opportunities that emerge from the CMU process.

Realising the growth potential of the IFS sector relies to a large extent on the availability of high quality education and skills. Ireland already has a high skilled workforce.

The IFS sector is competing with other sectors, including domestic FS employers and leading multinational corporations, for graduates in disciplines such as ICT, engineering, mathematics, data analytics, business and law. This competition for talent has been accentuated in more recent years as the convergence between ICT and IFS has accelerated.

The Strategy seeks to address this though a number of different processes with the aim of ensuring that there is availability of the relevant talents and qualifications to ensure that your business can thrive in Ireland.

Another important goal of the Strategy is to drive research, innovation and entrepreneurship in the IFS sector.

Many of the world’s leading and emerging technology and financial services companies have strategic international operations in Ireland. But Ireland is also establishing a strong global reputation for innovative FinTech start-ups. The start-up rate for Irish-owned FinTech companies is accelerating rapidly. As a result Ireland, along with the UK, captures most of the FinTech venture investment occurring in Europe.

Our big tech and big data advantages are many. The company listings, spanning Apple to Zynga, reads like a who's who in the ICT hall of fame. While Amazon, Microsoft, Google, and Apple setting up data centres across the country prove that Irish clouds really do have a silver lining.

We have recently seen Realex acquired by Global Payments for €115m and Currency Fair raising €10m on the markets to fund their further expansion.

We are seeing significant investment and enthusiasm around the Fintech sector. This is a valuable niche in the international marketplace Ireland can really put its stamp on. Taking on the mantle of a premier global Fintech hub is an opportunity that requires an alignment and leveraging of the many advantages Ireland has worked long and hard to achieve.

The changes arising in the provision of financial services from the technological changes are transformative.

Indeed I was at an event in Frankfurt last week to support Irish financial technology companies in their efforts to win business in the German market. I was impressed at the dedication and level of skills and commercial acumen I saw and hope to see more of such events.

Indeed, the IFS 2020 Strategy contains a number of actions to help ensure we have an effective Fintech ecosystem which addresses the needs of start-ups and scaling companies in terms of funding, skills, mentors, accelerators while at the same time addressing the needs of foreign-owned IFS multinationals. The ultimate aim is to make Ireland a global leader for Fintech.

Regulation and IFS 2020

Ensuring that the operating environment remains transparent and competitive is a key factor that will underpin the strategy’s success.

It is important to note the Central Bank’s independent role in terms of regulation. This is vital to ensure confidence in the regulation of the financial services sector in Ireland. We have had too many problems in the past for this to change.

However I would say that the IFS2020 Strategy should improve the alignment and line of sight between all the important stakeholders, which does, of course, include the Central Bank

The Central Bank have publicly published authorisation standard reports that benchmarks their performance against operational and other targets. The issuance of those reports allows for consultation and feedback from industry and the public, allowing for greater transparency and dialogue between the policy makers and the IFS sector at large.

It is always useful to consider the level or implementation of standards. It allows for a new evaluation of how standards are developed and implemented – this of course does not mean a diminution in standards.

As the financial services sector evolves and changes, the regulators and the policy makers cannot stand still. Where it is possible to make changes to improve the quality but also the transparency of the regulatory process, we should aim to do so as much as possible. Greater transparency in processes can however lead to improved accountability and acceptance and understanding of regulation and regulatory processes.

In that context and as part of the IFS 2020 strategy the Central Bank and the Department of Finance are, in accordance with their respective legal roles, to review the authorisation service standards reported by the Central Bank this year.

I think this will be a useful and productive exercise and complement the other measures in the strategy.

Implementation

Clearly all the aims in IFS 2020 will not be achieved without an appropriate implementation process.

The implementation structures of IFS 2020 with a high level group chaired by me and involving both the public sector and private industry should ensure that issues within and ancillary to the Strategy are considered and prioritised for action. This will allow for issues of interest to be considered by the sector.

In addition, the Strategy is intended to be flexible to cope with the challenges to be addressed. Indeed, an important part of the approach in dealing with the Strategy is the recognition that it will change and evolve over the next five years.

The implementation structure involving the public sector and industry in problem solving mode in tandem with the flexible nature of the strategy is in my view a way of achieving positive outcomes for all financial services providers and for the industry as a whole.

Conclusion

The theme of today’s event is Strategically Positioning IFS.

I believe that the financial services sector in Ireland faces and will continue to face challenges. There are local, national and global competitive challenges which we must and will face.

We have a strong competitive position but we cannot afford to stand still. The IFS strategy is part of the process of remaining competitive now and in the future.

Thank you.

In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X68-4W11-DYS1-0220-00000-00Ireland needs a plan for White House contender and Big Tech critic Warren2019-10-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:55ZLexisNexisFINANCEPg. 10Ireland needs a plan for White House contender and Big Tech critic WarrenMark Paul

On most issues, the surging US presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren's catchphrase is that she has "a plan for that". Her centrepiece business policies would define the epoch for certain companies located here. As she strides to the front of the Democrat field, what is Ireland's plan for Warren?

Leaked audio this week from an internal Facebook meeting included a promise by its chief executive Mark Zuckerberg to fight Warren's anti-monopoly plans to "break up Big Tech" should she reach the White House. She has specifically threatened to go after Facebook, Google and Amazon, which all have major operations in Dublin.

"If she gets elected president, then I would bet that we will have a legal challenge, and I would bet that we will win the legal challenge," Zuckerberg said, in the comments leaked to theverge.com. "If someone's going to try to threaten something that existential, you go to the mat and you fight."

Fight With an officially-claimed 15,000 Irish jobs at the three companies combined, the Government would feel it had a dog in that fight. Which dog, is the question.

Here is Ireland's Warren quandary: Big Tech might be a big employer here, but she is completely correct about the need to rein in Facebook, Google and Amazon. With a combined market cap of $2.1 trillion (EUR 1.9 trillion) they are too big and powerful to adequately regulate. It is an economic and social imperative that they be broken up, even though that could damage their ability to invest in Ireland.

If it's not Warren, it will be somebody else eventually. If US or EU sheriffs come to bust up Big Tech, Ireland, as their international home (in the case of Facebook and Google) and regulatory safe harbour, must decide - play along or play the fool? The State's international reputation was sullied for being on the wrong side of history over corporate tax avoidance. Ireland cannot afford to be the bad guy yet again, if this State appeared to back anything other than the international greater good.

Warren's thesis on Big Tech is straightforward. She argues that Google, Facebook and Amazon, by dint of their scale and ability to kill off competitors, as well as their vast troves of data, have too much power over economies, societies, and democracies.

"They've bulldozed competition, used our private information for profit, and tilted the playing field against everyone else," she wrote in March. Outside of Mountainview, Menlo Park and Seattle, and perhaps Silicon Docks in Dublin, who could argue against her while keeping a straight face?

Warren cites an eMarketer claim that Amazon was on course for 50 per cent of the US e-commerce market by the end of 2018, eight times the share of its nearest rival, eBay. Meanwhile, Facebook's terrifying power is illustrated in the blame it gets for facilitating bad actors to influence elections, such is its omnipresence. As for Google, when is the last time you even contemplated using another search engine? The rest are pygmies and will remain so, which makes Google competitively immovable.

"As these companies have grown larger and more powerful, they have used their resources and control over the way we use the internet to squash small businesses and innovation, and substitute their own financial interests for the broader interests [of society]," Warren argues, with some justification.

She says Big Tech companies have used mergers to limit competition, such as Facebook's purchases of Instagram and WhatsApp. She also accuses them of a conflict of interest by controlling "proprietary marketplaces" or trading platforms, such as Amazon Marketplace, while at the same time participating in the platforms as sellers against other competitors.

Firstly, Warren proposes passing laws to designate major tech companies with trading marketplaces as "platform utilities". They would be forced to hive off their own trading arms from the platforms, to ensure their own businesses didn't get favourable treatment. She'd also ban them from sharing data with each other.

"Amazon Marketplace, Google's ad exchange, and Google Search would be platform utilities under this law. Therefore, Amazon Marketplace and Basics, and Google's ad exchange and businesses on the exchange would be split apart. Google Search would have to be spun off as well," she says.

Secondly, she says she would appoint regulators to unwind Facebook's purchases of Instagram and WhatsApp; Google's buyouts of Waze, Next and DoubleClick; and Amazon's deals for Whole Foods and Zappos.

"Unwinding these mergers will promote healthy competition in the market, which will put pressure on big tech companies to be more responsive to user concerns, including about privacy," she argues. Imagine Facebook and Instagram as competitors trying to outdo each other to protect their users' data?

If Warren topples Trump and takes the White House, it would present a genuine dilemma for Ireland, were she to follow through with her plans.

Cuddle up

The Government has made a strategic choice to cuddle up to Google and Facebook, in particular. One has only to read the cringe-worthy exchanges of mutual fawning between Leo Varadkar and Zuckerberg, released recently under Freedom of Information.

Yet it's easy to say he should have given Zuckerberg hell for the negative attention Facebook has brought on Ireland for its exotic tax practices and its management of user data. But he can't just tell such a large employer to take a hike. Arguably, given Facebook's level of investment, the Taoiseach was merely acting in the immediate national interest. So long as he doesn't forget Ireland's long-term interests.

Whatever about Amazon, if Google and Facebook are broken up, the landscape will change on Silicon Docks.

Footnote

The announcement of the impending elevation of little-known Corkman Ken Murphy to the top job at Tesco, as group chief executive, had many in the City of London's Square Mile scratching their heads.

When he takes over next summer, he will have big shoes to fill as the replacement for "Drastic" Dave Lewis (inset), whom one analyst said on Wednesday will be forever known as the "bloke who saved Tesco" from obliteration by the grocery discounters.

They know Murphy well at Munster rugby club, however. When the club put together a commercial advisory board of big hitters in the dog days of 2012, the former Walgreens Boots Alliance chief commercial officer was one of those to whom it turned. Until he moved to the US four years ago, Murphy served alongside prominent names such as Digicel's Leslie Buckley and Greencore's Patrick Coveney.

Munster's commercial board is chaired by the business blue-blood Niall FitzGerald, the former chairman and chief executive of Unilever, a rival of Procter & Gamble where Murphy started his career in consumer goods.

Boots, where Murphy soldiered for most of his career, would have been a client of Greencore's sandwich supply business. By all accounts, it was Greencore's Coveney and FitzGerald who identified the Corkman to come on board at Munster. Murphy was also seemingly a handy rugby player in his day, and played for Munster at underage level.

His former Munster colleagues were impressed and say Murphy brought innovative ideas to the table. He is said to have been especially influential in pushing Munster to seek commercial tie-ups with educational institutions.

When US giant Walgreens took full control of Boots Alliance in 2015, Murphy, who had been based in Nottingham, moved to Chicago for a senior role and left the Munster commercial board. He didn't cut his links with the club entirely, however, and has been spotted about the place for big games.

He quit his US job last December and moved his family back across the Atlantic, although he kept a consultancy role at Walgreeens.

Company records show he set up an Irish company, along with his wife Olga, a few days before Christmas, called Mistletonia. It subsequently changed its name to Retail & Consumer Insights, and remains registered to a Donnybrook, Dublin 4 address. Surely that must be considered behind enemy lines for a Munster man?

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:606F-BP51-JCW9-23B4-00000-00Ireland needs more muscle to police tech giants, EU report says2020-06-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:55ZLexisNexisBUSINESS NEWSIreland needs more muscle to police tech giants, EU report says

[timgcapimported=The report said that data protection agencies across the 27-country bloc had increased staff by 42% increase and budgets by 49% between 2016-2019, but the Irish and Luxembourg governments needed to do more. Picture:Reuters]2ccd8a70-850f-4440-8d0c-305f04c42fe5__3dca9bcb-d3a8-49a5-b0b4-b90eff2b3997.jpg[/timgcapimported]

Ireland and Luxembourg, European headquarters to Google, Facebook, Twitter and Amazon, need a substantial boost in resources to deal with data breaches by US tech giants, a European Union report said.

The report by the European Commission, seen by Reuters, sought to assess the effectiveness of the EU's landmark General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) rules adopted in 2018.

GDPR requires companies to seek people's consent before using their personal data or face steep fines. European Vice President for Values and Transparency Vera Jourova has previously lauded the rules as a compass to guide the EU into the digital age.

The report said that data protection agencies across the 27-country bloc had increased staff by 42% increase and budgets by 49% between 2016-2019, but the Irish and Luxembourg governments needed to do more.

"Given that the largest big tech multinationals are established in Ireland and Luxembourg, the data protection authorities of these countries act as lead authorities in many important cross-border cases and may need larger resources than their population would otherwise suggest," the report said.

The Irish watchdog has opened cases into Facebook, Facebook-owned Instagram and WhatsApp as well as Twitter, Apple, Verizon Media, Microsoft-owned LinkedIn and US digital advertiser Quantcast.

The report urged national watchdogs to launch joint investigations that would lead to more harmonised rules and approaches.

It said some of the challenges were reconciling data privacy rights with the right to freedom of expression, and how to apply the rules to technologies such as artificial intelligence, facial recognition, blockchain and the internet of things.

Enforcement continues to be the weak link, said Eva Simon at the Civil Liberties Union for Europe.

Reuters

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5KPX-KCF1-DYS1-055B-00000-00Ireland needs to be 'sound' on the European question;There is now a low level of anger towards Ireland coming from both the Spanish public and government2016-09-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:02:55ZLexisNexisOPINIONPg. 14Ireland needs to be 'sound' on the European questionThere is now a low level of anger towards Ireland coming from both the Spanish public and governmentJoe Haslam

On the surface relations between the Irish and the Spanish have never been better. Last year over a million people from Ireland visited Spain, more than France, Italy and Portugal combined.

From a low base 20 years ago, Irish-managed companies are now doing very well here. Ryanair is the number one airline in Spain in terms of passenger traffic, and 8.2 million people in Spain have bought something in Primark, more than even the Spanish home-grown Zara.

Yet to those of us living here long enough to be well integrated can detect a low level of anger towards Ireland both in government and among the Spanish public. I will give two examples.

A banker told me that Ireland was increasingly seen as place you could issue debt when the banks in Spain will not lend you any more money. "They should have had to sell assets, but you lot gave him more money."

An executive from Sareb, Spain's bad bank, complained about the highly favourable terms offered to private equity firms by Nama. "No euro zone country should be falling over like that to help those guys," he said.

In technology circles the anger is even greater, with start-ups losing their technical staff to the bright lights of Silicon Docks in Dublin and elsewhere. Any defence that Ireland just created the right investment climate is given short shrift.

"Those big tech companies are only there as you allow them to transfer most of the profits from around Europe"

If you are used to the words Irish and Ireland bringing nothing but a great big smile, such treatment can be quite a jolt.

There is no great Boston or Berlin debate in Spain. Rich and poor alike expect high-quality public services in health, education and transport. Many people who have private healthcare through their employer prefer to use the public system. Similarly, many parents I know send their children to public school, dismissing any notion that private is automatically better.

While centre-right politicians here express their admiration for (and even name streets after) Margaret Thatcher, they do not share her antipathy towards the role of the state. Over the last five years the government led by prime minister Mariano Rajoy has cut education and health spending by EUR 16 billion. At just over 1 per cent of GDP it is not an insignificant figure but he did not dare to cut it by more.

Reluctance

Up to now populist ire for the cuts has been directed towards the continued existence of special investment vehicles that allow the wealthy to avoid taxes. However, the outcome of the EU Commission investigation into Apple has highlighted the Irish Government's reluctance to, at the very least, ask more questions of foreign multinationals.

This week in the European Parliament, Spanish EPP MEP Pablo Zalba Bidegain said: "We must say loud and clear that the party is over. Although multinationals create jobs, they must pay taxes and we need a consolidated tax basis."

Also members of the EPP are Fine Gael MEPs Brian Hayes and Sean Kelly, both of whom spoke in opposition to the ruling.

An old joke among the major oil companies is that in Spain it is not possible to know where the energy company Repsol ends and where the ministry for energy begins. The same could be said for the other large utilities on the IBEX35 such as Telefonica, Iberdrola and Endesa.

Although private companies, they are seen as having strategic national importance. In exchange for having their interests always taken into consideration, they are expected to pay their fair share of corporation tax.

They do, of course, take measures to reduce the burden, but never to minimise it to anything near the 0.005 per cent Apple paid on its European profits in 2014.

The image of Ireland has been dragged by association into the world of the Panama Papers, Lux Leaks and the Lagarde list.

It did not help that the Irish Government rushed so forcefully to Apple's defence. Something more nuanced like "while we support Apple's decision to appeal the ruling, we also support the amendment to Accounting Directive (Directive 2013/34/EU) to ensure that large groups publish annually a report disclosing the profit and the tax accrued and paid in each member state on a country-by-country basis" would have gone down better in Madrid and Brussels.

Tremendous benefit

Is there any argument but that our membership of Europe has been of tremendous benefit to Ireland, and that the Atlanticist Fantasy of our nearest neighbour is not a credible alternative?

Brexit means that the era of Ireland riding two horses as the acceptable face of the Anglo Saxon world is over.

The UK saying "cheerio" means we will have to get on board with an agenda of closer integration or continue to have more days as a lonely minority as Hayes and Kelly had this week.

This will not be easy. As a nation we like to be friends with everyone. We are not good at taking sides. However, as both my Latin American and African students remind me, some of the things people like most about the Irish are our ability to side with little guy against injustice.

The EU has its faults, but we should be in there fighting to ensure that corporations pay tax where they generate profits, that justice is done in public and not by secret investor courts, and that companies in breach of consumer regulations lose access to EU markets.

Many a political career in Ireland was derailed over doubts as to whether he or she was "sound on the national question".

Maybe now it is time we should rephrase the question, and ask if he or she is "sound on the European question"? Joe Haslam is an associate professor at the IE Business School in Madrid
